@TyberiusMaximus Yes, because it is nominal GDP. GDP measured in devaluing dollars.

The reason why it is naturally understated on debt/GDP charts is because all of this fiscal spending was highly inflationary, and thus boosted nominal GDP quite significantly.

Nominal GDP more than doubled during that time, even as debt-to-GDP soared from 40% to over 100%.

Back in the 1940s during WWII, public debt to GDP quickly jumped from 40% to over 100%.

Either way, the network's energy usage is limited by the amount of utility it provides.

People often extrapolate a brief period of time into infinity, but that's not how things work. The network's design for the long run is different than its design for the bootstrapping phase.

In the long run, it's the combo of adoption and efficiency improvements that matters.

-If Bitcoin adoption stagnates, its energy usage will stagnate and decline.

-If Bitcoin adoption continues, then it will use a decent amount of energy but in an increasingly efficient way. https://t.co/52sk35f26G

From here, higher layers of the Bitcoin stack (e.g. the Lightning network and/or federated environments) will need to do the scaling, or perhaps some future soft forks.

Fee pressure, if/when it occurs, can drive adoption of those upper layers and incentivize new development.

A lot of people who think bitcoin will become insecure due to lack of fees, don't take into account Segwit adoption- they seem to think transfer volume is stagnant.

Volume is growing a lot, but in an increasingly efficient way.

Ever since the Segwit soft fork was introduced, whenever bitcoin fees get high, it results in a new spike of Segwit adoption- the network gets more efficient over time.

Eventually, this'll get maxed out. If volume keeps climbing, it would start creating upward fee pressure. https://t.co/PkkB4Rf89L

Some people argue that Bitcoin uses (or will use) too much energy.

Ironically, other people argue that Bitcoin eventually won't use enough energy to be secure, once the block subsidy mostly goes away.

(Both camps tend to advocate for other blockchains.)

Bitcoin's annual monetary velocity is pretty volatile.

If you adjust it to exclude quick hops for things like mixers and exchange shuffling (e.g. the Coin Metrics' version), it's a lot less volatile. https://t.co/bAwhvmpV3X
The Bitcoin network processed nearly $15 trillion worth of transfer volume in 2022. https://t.co/FNYH8S9z6z

Bitcoin mining revenue grows more slowly than market cap and transfer volume, as the block subsidy winds down and trends towards transaction fees only.

This is what people get wrong when they incorrectly think that bitcoin's energy usage is an exponential problem. https://t.co/g84TG78Q6J

Egypt is a country of 100+ million people, and there are many countries like them. Nigeria and Brazil are each 200+ million.

Billions of people live in countries with junk-rated sovereign bonds, and by extension, junk-rated currency. https://t.co/vCETI0u58E

Exit valves include accumulating physical cash dollars, or holding dollars in local banks (which might be converted back to local currency in a crisis), or buying a lot of gold, or locking savings up in additional illiquid real estate beyond what they otherwise would.

For people in US, Canada, Europe, Australia, etc, our local currency usually loses value slowly. It's investment-grade.

For tons of people around the world, the default currency they interact with and save with is junk-rated. Their liquid net worth sits in junk-rated assets. https://t.co/avtS5s9kzt

If you ask someone, "should you put your liquid net worth in junk bonds?" the obvious answer is no.

Egypt's bonds are junk-rated, which by extension means their currency is too.

So, Egyptians' savings are generally in junk-rated currency, just due to where they live. https://t.co/giX5cOlFG6

A big potential battle over the next decade will not likely be about what assets you can or cannot own, but rather, whether you are entitled to any privacy and whether you are entitled to custody your own assets.

Privacy is increasingly being framed as abnormal; something only bad people want.

Keep in mind, privacy isn't just about privacy from governments. It's also about privacy from corporations, privacy from potential attackers and hacks, etc.

Remember, physical cash is already a private medium of exchange. It used to be ubiquitous and normal, but as digital payments became commonplace, governments are clamping down on cash.

Their allowance for privacy is reducing.
https://t.co/zWSqLMaztO

Getting these types of technologies to comply with bank laws will be like when they tried to get automobiles to comply with horse-and-carriage laws.

And to even try, they have to get rather draconian/authoritarian in their laws and enforcement. "You can't run that free code".

It's a very different thing for a government to say (and then try to enforce), "you're not allowed to write that type of open source code" or "you're not allowed to run that type of open source software on your own laptop".

It's one thing for a government to say, "banks can't send money to country xyz" or "banks have to get information xyz on their customers".

People put up with that, and often don't even know about it.

Mainly, it's easy for a government to enforce banks and other large businesses to follow certain rules.

But it's hard and expensive to enforce these types of things on the consumer level. There are orders of magnitude more enforcement points.

It's inevitable that some governments will try to make peer-to-peer open-source value transfer networks follow the same KYC AML laws that banks do.

However, that's going to be very hard for them to do over the long run.

Interview discussing the FTX/Alameda collapse, jurisdictional/regulatory arbitrage and risks, the increasing separation between the bitcoin ecosystem and the crypto ecosystem, price action, and the utility of stablecoins:

@MohamedFFouda @ImMetaverseMaxi @PeterMcCormack Money is for saving and for buying any product or service in the world that accepts the money.

Why build use cases for money? Instead, improve money so that it can be used for more and more existing things.

@cyounessi1 @Swagtimus @ETHbenezer @ImMetaverseMaxi @PeterMcCormack Ironically, I do get attacked by some bitcoiners (not many, and not with large followings) for being "too open" to Ethereum when I steelman it as part of my analysis.

They'll isolate a paragraph where I said something constructive on it and be like, "Oh look, Lyn promotes ETH."

@cyounessi1 @Swagtimus @ETHbenezer @ImMetaverseMaxi @PeterMcCormack It's a fallacy to assume that the truth is always somewhere in the middle. If you review something in detail, and determine that side A is more correct than side B, than there is no requirement to argue as though it's an equal dispute between A and B.

@cyounessi1 @Swagtimus @ETHbenezer @ImMetaverseMaxi @PeterMcCormack Millions of people came into the industry since then, an order of magnitude more, and it is marketed to them as though all chains are the same.

A ledger with an unforgeable history is a massive innovation. People are interested in understanding the difference.

@toghrulmaharram @Swagtimus @ETHbenezer @ImMetaverseMaxi @PeterMcCormack 1) Humans determining the canon history, for lack of unforgeable history, is absolutely governance.

2) In order to be eclipsed in bitcoin, you would need to be permanently eclipsed. Otherwise, if there is a heavier chain out there being broadcast, you can find it eventually.

@toghrulmaharram @Swagtimus @ETHbenezer @ImMetaverseMaxi @PeterMcCormack PoS inherently involves governance, unless perhaps the checkpoints are regularly put into a PoW blockchain. 

Because if the PoS chain goes down with no unforgeable self-verifiable history, then some oligopoly decides how to restart.

@sabroshi1 @Swagtimus @ImMetaverseMaxi @PeterMcCormack I only bring it up when people bring up to me how much development is happening on Ethereum or how decentralized it is (as they wait for developers to allow unstaking, and as developers issue their roadmaps).

I'm not the one who went to their threads about it, lol.

@Swagtimus @ImMetaverseMaxi @PeterMcCormack I was being ironic on purpose, because bitcoiners often get called toxic whereas I've receive considerable aggression from ETH folks (way more than from Tesla folks actually, and I've been critical of that ecosystem too).

But I rarely see good counter-arguments, unfortunately.

@Swagtimus @ETHbenezer @ImMetaverseMaxi @PeterMcCormack There's no unforgeable history. If a node goes offline and comes back, it relies on trust again, rather than self-variable history.

If the chain goes down, there is no self-verifiable proof for what the correct history is.

@Swagtimus @ETHbenezer @ImMetaverseMaxi @PeterMcCormack There's a big difference between one bootstrap, and the ever-present need for continual bootstrapping and trust.

Plus, if a longer PoW chain exists anywhere, it can be discovered. One chain has a tremendous amount of computation proven on it.

@Swagtimus @ETHbenezer @ImMetaverseMaxi @PeterMcCormack Not in Ethereum. In other PoS systems (some of them actually understand the inherent shortcomings of PoS).

So in Ethereum, the history remains forgeable.

@ETHbenezer @Swagtimus @ImMetaverseMaxi @PeterMcCormack Ironically, one of the proposed solutions to that fundamental issue, is to regularly checkpoint PoS blockchains into the Bitcoin blockchain and use that as the fallback authority.

Because that's what PoW does. It makes an unforgeable history that is self-verifiable.

@ETHbenezer @Swagtimus @ImMetaverseMaxi @PeterMcCormack PoS has no unforgeable history of the ledger.

If it goes down for any reason, it's costless to create alternative histories, and so it requires oligopolistic authority/checkpoints to assert the canon history.

@Swagtimus @ImMetaverseMaxi @PeterMcCormack I would say the "move too fast, break stuff" already occurred when it was implemented without withdraws anywhere in sight and with an unclear timeline.

That kind of thing is why I view it as an equity- an investment contract based on the work of others.

@Swagtimus @ImMetaverseMaxi @PeterMcCormack I think the Ethereum community needs to work on its toxicity problem.

I get hundreds of replies from ETH enthusiasts (generally in threads that have nothing to do with ETH) and insults from them outweigh substantive dialogue by a wide margin.

@kendallweihe @PrestonPysh @LukeGromen Yes, if the interest rate on Treasury debt is high, it's basically a larger deficit that is flowing into the economy. At a smaller scale, the Fed is also injecting money into the banking system.

But that's competing with a slowdown in lending.

@PrestonPysh @LukeGromen They seem to do deferred shenanigans to avoid the appearance of the Fed having negative equity.

But it would be easier to avoid the Fed having negative equity in the first place, if they could save some of their profits as an actual capital buffer to later draw down from.

@PrestonPysh @LukeGromen Yeah, basically.

More normal accounting would be:

1) All Fed profits get remit to the Treasury, except some percent (let's say 25%) that gets set aside as a reserve, a Fed asset that accumulates.

2) Any potential losses subtract from that reserve.
@PrestonPysh @LukeGromen So it's a deferred asset for the Fed and a deferred liability to the Treasury.

@PrestonPysh @LukeGromen I guess they call it a "deferred asset" because those credits represent the fact that the Fed gets to pay themselves before resuming sending money back to the Treasury.

Rather than owing money to the Treasury, they get to dig out of a hole first, then resume paying.

@PrestonPysh @LukeGromen In order to go back to paying the Treasury on a regular basis, they would need to 1) become profitable again and 2) use the initial period of profits to pay off those accumulated deferred liabilities.

@PrestonPysh @LukeGromen The Fed has to send their profits to the Treasury.

If they have a loss instead, then it becomes a deferred liability, and the next time they make a profit and *would* send it to the Treasury, they instead use it to pay off part or all of that accumulated liability.

@smilepimp What part of my original post had a complaint in it?

It was an observation based on a popular nationwide chain.

Basically, during the 2010s decade, the bigger bubble was arguably in bonds compared to stocks.

Stocks became rather richly-priced by the end of the decade and into 2020/2021, but the super-low bond yields, and *negative* yields in some places, were the bigger anomaly.

I use this as an example of a quintessential blue-chip stock.

You get similar results when looking at most consumer staples stocks that have multi-decade histories of consecutive annual dividend increases.

Coca Cola, for example: https://t.co/uLq88HX5XB

Back in the 1990s, Coke stock was very overvalued. By the 2010s, it was back down to a pretty sensible valuation. Its valuation then creeped back up, but not as high as before.

There was an atypical period in the 2010s decade where Procter and Gamble stock had a higher dividend yield than the 10-year US Treasury note.

@JoeCarlasare @letsnotfight @john_at_swan @Benny_Stacks @mishcharts They do include price inflation. The point is, those price increases *were not adjusted out*.

@JoeCarlasare @letsnotfight @john_at_swan @Benny_Stacks @mishcharts Because they're just nominal dollar values of the purchases. They're not # of units sold. Prices are higher now, so that affects nominal dollar values as one of the components (along with volumes and types of goods sold).

Unlike Taiwan, Mainland China is still sticking with their zero-Covid approach. That hockey-stick chart of deaths occurring upon full re-opening is probably what some of their leaders fear.

But the question is how long they can maintain the cost of constant lockdowns.

Basically, as the virus mutated towards higher transmissibility and lower fatality, trying to completely stop it became increasingly untenable. So as facts changed, they changed policies.

Every policy has a cost.

14k deaths is tragic, of course. But with its 24 million population, Taiwan has hundreds of thousands of deaths per year as a normal baseline.

All of these 14k COVID deaths represent 0.06% of their population, and mostly concentrated in the 75+ demographic.

Taiwan used a zero-Covid strategy for a while, but back in spring of this year after the Omicron wave, they pivoted their strategy towards re-opening and living with it.

In terms of deaths, it was like ripping a band-aid off as people became exposed for the first time. https://t.co/jxcycZeE62

@xCryptoAnarchy It's an adoption question. If it in 15 years not enough people use bitcoin, then its censorship-resistance will decrease. If that starts to happen, then users can pay higher fees to regain censorship resistance.

That is why "crypto is a scam" tends to be a reasonable heuristic. It usually is.

But global decentralized peer-to-peer value transfer and self-custody: that's something that macro folks need to keep exploring, imo.

In other words, they want the rewards before the proven business model.

Traditional VC needs to go through a corporate acquisition or public SEC-approved offering for a broad exit.

Token VC, using regulatory arbitrage, can exit on retail before their project is proven at all.

The reason that many people want to add a blockchain and token to things, is for seigniorage and fast exit liquidity.

Devs+VCs want to get funding via a token, make a project, and then exit the project on retail investors prior to it being a self-sustaining business idea.

Most of what is being done with "crypto" can be done better and more efficiently without a blockchain.

Bearer-asset self-referential money that solves the double-spending problem: a blockchain is good for this.

Outside of that, blockchains often are not the best solution.

Most crypto projects sacrifice some degree of decentralization to "do more". This could mean more throughput, or more expressivity, etc.

But if you sacrifice decentralization, you lose the part that is actually innovative and valuable here.

In other words, many macro people opining on bitcoin as a technical protocol, come off like opining about a company while not understanding the product or the company financials.

Blockchain trilemma? Nodes? Bandwidth? Hard forks? Soft forks? Smart contracts? Federations? What?

A lot of macro articles from people that criticize bitcoin+crypto together as though they are one thing, are pretty transparently from authors who haven't personally used bitcoin or any crypto, can't tell you off-the-cuff what Segwit or Taproot are, etc.

It faces ongoing risks and needs to be continually explored, but it's tremendously interesting and has survived 14 years of hardcore testing and various boom/bust cycles so far.

That's why in addition to holding some, I also deploy capital into VC to build things using its tech.

Creating a scarce digital asset, solving the double-spending problem- that's a real innovation.

A decentralized global ledger.

Now, people can store+transfer value globally without going through banks.

People shouldn't write that off, when thinking about tech trends and macro.

One thing that a lot of bitcoin people and macro people share in common, is that they criticize the "crypto" industry.

A difference is that many macro people haven't done the fundamental research of self-custodying and transferring bitcoin as a bearer asset yet, as a test.

I love Twitter, regardless of ownership. The prior ownership had flaws. The current ownership, like any change, presents both opportunities and risks.

The platform itself is really hard to kill, due to network effects.

There are ways to make it exceptional, and ways to harm it.

Posting bitcoin collateral as a separate non-KYC orange check "skin in the game" method is useful.

Hashcash proof-of-work was originally designed by @adam3us as an anti-spam tool.

That way, anon accounts can also get certain features and have a cost for impersonation.

In other words, blue checks should be seen as a cost, not a perk or status. It means the account is large enough to face impersonators, and pays to support the platform, get UX perks, and avoid followers getting scammed.

The anon version can be an orange check, proof-of-work.

Corporations, organizations, and large public-facing individuals, are generally fine with KYC.

The point is to prove that "Yes, this McDonald's account is really McDonald's. No, it is not Bobby in his parent's basement trolling you, or Vlad in Russia scamming you."

But *required* KYC sucks. Screw that.

Voluntary KYC is fine. The reason that some large public-facing accounts want to KYC for some form of verification, is to reduce impersonator scams.

It breaks my heart if someone pretends to be Lyn Alden and scams people into something.

Blue checks shouldn't be some weird arbitrary status symbol. It should be a tool to prevent impersonation.

Something like "if you have over 10k followers, and are willing to do voluntary KYC and pay for Twitter Blue, you can be verified".

It's a cost, not a status.

So, I support Twitter asking large accounts to pay for added perks. Payers get UX features, anti-impersonation tools, etc.

Paying to boost their comments over non-paying accounts, however, is concerning.

"Step aside plebs, the monied folks are talking." Yuck.

Some people say that large accounts should be paid, rather than have to pay. For example, YouTube pays you for content creation.

I disagree. That only works if ads are profitable on the platform. YouTube creators put ads in their videos, but Tweeters don't put ads in our tweets.

IMO good ideas:

-Pay for added features (longer videos, edits, fewer/no ads).
-Voluntary KYC process for large public accounts.
-Orange check implementation. Non-KYC proof of work verification (via @saylor).
-Toggle for "followers of followers can comment" (via @nvk)

The application process for the "blue check" status as an anti-impersonation tool was arbitrary, broken, and needed to be fixed.

But paying to get posts boosted over non-payers is not great for "free speech"- it reduces the voices of less wealthy people.

@jayskywalker16 @ThHappyHawaiian @shad0w239 If we cannot assay, audit, or transport gold, then its usefulness would reduce considerably. We would only stop those things if gold demand flatlines.

As a useful settlement network, gold requires energy, even though the units do not. Same for bitcoin in that sense.

@Z_fucking_gg @ThHappyHawaiian @shad0w239 Basically, since bitcoin is both a unit and its own settlement network (doing the transport, assay, and auditing of those units), it is best compared with another active network rather than just the unit of another network.

And all networks need energy to be active.

And so, the Social Security trust draws down its Treasury stockpile to cover the difference between inflows and outflows.

A multi-decade Treasury buyer is now a seller, until the trust depletes in the mid-2030s.

For years, Social Security inflows exceeded outflows. They store this excess in US Treasuries for savings.

So, despite being part of the government, they hold Treasuries. This is called intra-government debt.

Now, due to retiring Baby Boomers,  outflows exceed inflows.

@CCoffeeCap Yes.

More specifically, they will still have incoming cash flows but those won't be enough to cover outflows. Outflows will need to be slashed 20% or more, or some other adjustment.
@BrianHChona @pzyxian Yes.
@redpill_finance They aren't buying anything. They are just drawing down their stockpile because cash outflows now exceed cash inflows.

@somebodyelse It doesn't *aim* for depletion. For years more money flowed in than out. Now that Baby boomers are in retirement, more goes out than in, until it is projected to run out in 2035. So, they sell their Treasury stash.

Depletion depends on inflation, rates, number of workers etc.

But Satoshi's innovation was the idea of a decentralized ledger.

It sacrifices most other aspects to try to remain as globally decentralized as possible.

People who left the Soviet Union could only take $100 USD with them. There was obviously no peer-to-peer self-custodial internet money at the time.

A global decentralized ledger, that anyone with an internet connection can access, is a powerful thing.

Some issues with DeFi:

1) It doesn't get around the fiat on-ramp problem. It's just a post-fiat-onramp trading and leveraging environment.

2) In terms of total locked value, custodial stablecoins and custodial wrapped assets are a very big percentage.

I critique DeFi as a general trend, but it's out of honest analysis, not bad faith.

Some DeFi proponents respond with insults, defensiveness, and tribalism, while others engage more constructively.

I recommend objectivity and constructiveness. It's good for your health.

Entirely organized in a decentralized way by private market participants.

@BitcoinIsSaving Custody is a basic contract type with a history as old as civilization, not some weird outlier contract. Governments using violence to eliminate all custody is very statist, massive overreach.

@BitcoinIsSaving I think any potential innovation from government-mandated mainchain-clogging, would be more than offset by the costs of such overreach, such as driving out small buyers, or trying to force some sort of scaling fork (basically an attack on bitcoin at that point).

@BitcoinIsSaving Among the baseline minimum responsibilities of government, eg minarchy, is to enforce contracts.

@francoavalencia With PoW, you can prove that one proposed history of the ledger has more work than another.

With PoS, alternate histories of the ledger are nearly costless to create. So you can't prove that one is any more valid than the other. The past becomes negotiable.

@francoavalencia In PoS, if a node goes offline and comes back online, they have to trust the network rather than verify the longest chain.

Similarly, if a PoS network goes offline (e.g. Solana), there is no provable canon chain history. Requires manual restart or centralized checkpoints.

If a fiscal spiral happens, then government interest expense explodes and the budget deficit becomes even more unrecoverable. More and more debt is issued to pay interest on prior debt.

So, policymakers usually cap yields once that starts to happen. Financial repression instead.

Once a country is super highly indebted at the sovereign level (like over 130% of GDP or so), and has structural deficits that are politically and demographically hard to fix, then uncapped yields can cause a fiscal spiral, where both rates and debt levels skyrocket.

Sovereign debt, even when denominated in a country's own currency and majority-owed to domestic entities, matters once it gets too high.

As Japan's bond yields ran into their 0.25% yield cap, the currency was the release valve, devaluing Japanese peoples' savings: https://t.co/a6d79pMsbu

To this day, I don't regret it. Literally the best thing I ever did. Even that injurious day, I stayed in that fight. Even the master warned me not to risk certain things.

I got back up, fought hard, but increasingly realized I couldn't continue. I needed to drive home.

I then had to go to a surgeon, get blood sucked out of the kneecap, and all sorts of severe pains.

I walked on crutches for weeks, missed my tournament, and went to prom with a boyfriend in a weakened state. Such was life.

While kickboxing with someone under the master's watchful eye at age 18, at the top of my game, in preparation for a tournament, I broke my knee, out of nowhere.

A friend I fought weekly, broke it.

I got back up, tried to keep fighting, but it was obvious. I had to drive home.

Students had a joke of "old man strength". Youngins who were talented only felt soft but skillful.

Some 50+ year students were firemen. Their technique was weak, but they were made of iron.

Only the master had both. High technique plus made of iron. Had to experience it.

Like literally, I fought many people for years. Everyone basically felt the same.

But not this guy. Not someone who spent 40 years breaking baseball bats over his shin and teaching instructors.

When you hit him, it felt like pure iron. Unhuman. Unbeatable. Proof-of-work.

I had to commute to that school each time. Within a year I reached my goals, achieved my target ranks, impressed my new master, and felt good.

The master was made of iron, and took whatever I gave, and doubled it. It was painful, but rewarding.

Proof-of-work, no easy path.

After being a semi-instructor for a couple years, I tried to achieve second-degree black belt and it was a struggle. My instructor hadn't even achieved it yet.

So I switched to a different school. A true master, 6th degree, who taught the most advanced regional instructors.

During that decade, my entire focus was on winning fights.

I had poor hand-eye coordination; I sucked at softball, basketball, volleyball, etc.

But I knew how to rekt someone in a fight with hands and feet and wrestling, and advanced towards that path.

I started to climb in the ranks. I frankly had no inherent youthful talent, but I grinded through.

Eventually after many years I became the leader student in the school, and my first job was teaching private lessons on katas and fighting (and bo-staff katas, a weird side-hobby).

I met friends there, and became closer to them than my school friends.

When you fight with someone, you know learn to know them. Smaller classes, discipline, objective outcomes (win or get beat).

It became my passion. Get the higher rank. Be the best. Help other students.

When I was a kid, I used to get bullied at bus stops and schooling grounds. Rough neighborhood.  Trailer park.

Unlike many wimpy parents, my father said, "if someone hits you, hit them back harder so they never do it again."

He sent me to martial arts school, age 6, every day.

I've spent the past three years comparing the 2020s to the 1940s, and sadly it becomes more real each month.

My hope is that, through these turbulent times, various societies will choose the narrow path, the path of thinking, research, history, wisdom, and empathy.

The phrases "Love your enemies, and pray for those who persecute you" and "Forgive them, for they know not what they do" are some of the most powerful phrases in common lexicon.

The words transcend the specific metaphysics, for these statements. Words to live by, imo. Wisdom.

I think the more people that ask these types of questions, the more likely a society is to go down the narrow path of critical thinking and truth, with new leaders with fresh ideas and high integrity, empowering individuals, and solving society's biggest problems.

"What are the first and second-order trade-offs of a given thing?"

"Who is hurt by this thing? Who is helped by it? Who pretends to be hurt but is actually helped?"

"What is the strongest possible case against the ideals that I hold?"

Nobody has the answers for you. I certainly don't either. We're all figuring this out.

Amid energy crises, wars, leadership voids, and economic problems, key things to always ask are:

"What is the other side of the argument?"

"What would a wise person disagree with me on?"

It's not a bad time to re-read "Nineteen Eighty-Four" and "Fourth Turning".

And a good time to re-emphasize critical thinking skills. The polished robots and the charismatic pumpers that oppose them tend to *both* be highly flawed.

Be objective, be skeptical, search for truth.

Establishment media becomes sanitized and politicized talking points in this context. It's propaganda for lack of a better word.

Alternative media, on the other hand, often plays to the crowd. Their emphasis is rarely on truth either, but on emotion and tribalism.

Polarization.

Path #3, another broad path and one of chaos. Society becomes too divided to coalesce around anything, and devolves into culture war or civil war. Things aren't good, nobody can agree on what is causing it, so it must be the other side.

Path #2, a dark path but a broad path, is that society coalesces around strong leaders with extremist ideas and zero sum views of the world, blaming the "other", as they are increasingly unable to find the root causes of their own society's problems.

Path #1, an ideal path and a narrow path, is that society coalesces partially around strong leaders with new ideas and high integrity, building the next set of institutions, but with critical thinking and a lack of tribalism. Emphasis on decentralization and personal empowerment.

Populist leaders, meanwhile, often more genuine-sounding but unfortunately often prone to extremism, tend to lead to further polarization in society. They have solutions, but those solutions often involve some hate.

At this pivotal point, society goes down one of a few paths.

It's not a UK-specific thing. It's a US/UK/Europe thing. They sound like robots. Glassy-eyed.

Meanwhile, the Eurasian thing with Putin and Xi is one of authoritarianism. Suppressing dissension. Personality cults. No personal recourse. No freedom of speech or movement. Worse.

Understand people and take them on a journey from there.

There is great societal risk when crowds become too self-focused and echo-chambery. That's how wars develop, and that's how societies dissolve into disarray.

Steelman (strengthen) your opponent's views, and be able to mount a philosophically-consistent counter argument.

My positions tend to be pro-freedom.

That doesn't always mean libertarian, but realize that any law means that the government is able to do violence to enforce it.

I am very selective with what I think the government should be able to inflict violence on me or my peers about.

The world is very tribalistic during this time, as it historically is doing periods of great change. Many influencers are audience-captured. They have a financial incentive to play to a crowd.

I want to challenge the crowd, filter out the close-minded and accept the open-minded.

Learn to steelman rather than strawman your opposition, which means to understand the strongest possible interpretation of your opponent's argument, and then refute it (or if you agree with it, change your view and accept it).

Don't mischaracterize and then argue that version.

Libertarians were probably untriggered this time, but I've triggered them before too. üòâ

I don't intend to provoke on purpose, but my goal is to make people think.

I want people to understand why different people might see the world differently. And empathize, and disagree. ü§ù

I purposely provoked both right-leaning and left-leaning people tonight. The goal was to shake off ideological echo-chamber followers.

Sometimes I'll be right or wrong in your views but I focus on objectivity and rationality. Follow if you want that, unfollow if you don't.

Another negative example:

"Each citizen gets a CO2 quota, determined by the government. If you exceed it in a week, your money gets shut off, and our drones will follow you to ensure you don't transact some other way. But government and corporate elites can fly private jets."

Another positive example:

"This new tech makes an improvement in efficiency, or makes a certain clean energy more economic. Here's how we can optimize this seriously."

Another negative example:

"Let's propose a technology that isn't really economical or clean, but we'll pretend it is, by ignoring the downsides and emphasizing the strengths, for a policy win rather than a real-world physical win."

War happens and it's all messed up.

Another positive example:

"This type of energy usage isn't great. But actually, this other technology we've done the work on can give similar benefits or better, with fewer problems. Here's the XYZ details on what we need to get there."

The world explores it.

Negative example:

"Humans should use less energy, live more primitive lives, and give an opening for their adversaries to use more energy and dominate them. Because of this problem in 100 years. The world carries less humans in this model? So be it."

The world ignores it.

Positive example:

"Specific chemicals ABC are damaging the global ozone layer. This is bad because of XYZ. Here's the clear data. Do this small change, and it improves the problem a lot and allows it to recover." 

The world does it, and it recovers. Thanks, science!

The former is low time preference behavior. Optimizing long-run resources for human and planetary flourishing. Preserving un-reproducible old-growth habitats is important.

The latter is high time preference behavior. Faddish, unaware, and anti-humanistic.

DDoS is effective because it takes little effort. 

Genuine competition isn't DDoS. The reason there couldn't be thousands of fake/scam radios is because they were physical and took effort.

Imagine, for example, that once someone made the radio, there were immediately a thousand imitators, except the vast majority didn't work or had fake aspects to them.

A lot of people would call radios scams. And it would be understandable.

The challenge with bitcoin, however, is that it can be copied, altered, in myriad ways. This is unlike, say, gold.

The node network and hash rate can't be easily copied, however.

This helps avoid tribalism too.

It allows someone to say, "I understand your point, and I agree with you on xyz aspects regarding it, but I think this other thing takes precedence, and here's why."

And that becomes a discussion rather than an argument.

In other words, don't just have an opinion on a random issue-by-issue basis.

Try to have a more complete ethical framework so that when some of those issues conflict, you have a path forward on resolving it and knowing where you stand.

A useful self-awareness exercise for ethical or political decision-making is to build an internal hierarchy of values or goals.

That way, when some specific topics you care about conflict in some way, you have a process for evaluating and forming a conclusion.

The beatings will continue until energy supply is structurally improved.

If they suppress demand, the beating takes the form of recession. If they let demand rip (either by choice or if they have to support the sovereign bonds), then the beating takes the form of more inflation.

Reining in demand through monetary tightness doesn't fix the energy supply issues. If anything, it could make them worse (higher cost of capital, and somewhat suppressed pricing).

Doesn't matter though, that is not in their models. Tightening anyway. ;)

If the Fed doesn't tighten, people will complain. If the Fed tightens, different people will complain.

Their mandate and their models points them to tighten until either inflation is low, unemployment is high, or the Treasury market breaks beforehand.

The IMF will get mad, currencies will break, growth fund investors will write their letters, crypto people will complain, but it doesn't matter.

The Fed is going to tighten until they break the Treasury market or something adjacent to it, or get higher unemployment.

@StockBondTrader When bond yields go up, bond prices go down. Capping yields under 0.25% is the same as enforcing a floor price for those bonds.
The Bank of England, on the other hand, has far fewer exchange reserves, and a more acute energy crisis compared to Japan.

In addition to shifting the supply/demand balance, random interventions like that keep traders from pushing their bets too far, because at any moment the BOJ can intervene and send the USDJPY exchange rate spiking down, blowing through trader leverage.

If the yen depreciates too quickly or too far for the Bank of Japan's liking, they have the option of major currency intervention, potentially selling hundreds of billions in foreign exchange reserves to buy back yen. They did a small amount of this a month ago.

On one hand, the Bank of Japan welcomes a bit of currency devaluation. It boosts nominal GDP vs debt levels, helps exporters, etc. It is the inflate-the-debt-away playbook. But it is bad for savers and importers.

That's the incentive structure of a levered relative fiat system.

Early in the process of YCC the market kept testing how serious the Bank of Japan is to maintain it by actually buying the bonds they need to, and the answer has been "really serious". So now the market gives up on yields and people just exit the currency.

The Bank of Japan owns about half the Japanese government bond market and explicitly sets a floor price for the 10-year Japanese government bond (yield curve control at 0.25%) with an infinite balance sheet, and so the trading market has basically gone away.

@RealKeithWeiner It happened in March 2020 to Treasuries, despite a disinflationary shock. Foreign balance sheets *had* to sell to get dollars. Bid/ask spreads widened to huge levels and the market seized up, triggering an emergency Fed response.

What happened to the UK was similar but pensions.

Similarly, sovereign bond markets for countries with over 100% debt to GDP, can go almost no-bid quicker than market participants expect if the balance sheet capacity is full or levered, triggering an emergency central bank response (eg the UK last week).

For example, when the oil price went negative in April 2020, it was not because market participants assessed oil to have negative value.

It was because given the fast lockdown demand collapse, there was literally not enough storage capacity to hold the recent supply.

For the absolute biggest markets in the world, it is not just about the price, but about who has the sheer capacity to hold the assets.

During supply gluts in these markets, price at the margin is not set by assessment of value, but by hard storage constraints.

The end result is that in many instances, the environmentalist groups end up being worse for the environment in practice, due to unproductive priorities.

Clean air and water is important but we need to focus on the best ways to achieve that, not counterproductive ways.

Similarly, the environmentalist anti-nuclear movement in Europe has kept a lot of coal-burning on the grid when it could have otherwise been mostly phased out, thus contributing to more air pollution and CO2 emissions. https://t.co/43JOCPnIbn https://t.co/mVHQbBSzJx

Freezing, shipping, and unfreezing gas via expensive facilities and specialized ships (LNG) only makes economic sense when a domestic pipeline is not really an option but gas is still needed.

It would be like charging a Tesla with a portable gasoline generator- inefficient.

Plus, by avoiding pipelines and putting more demand on global LNG (which is limited), it puts pressure on global LNG prices and drives up the cost for developing countries that can least afford those costs. https://t.co/4fGfrrTZgz

Environmentalists often think that by blocking a pipeline it will mean less hydrocarbon use.

But instead it means that it is transported by rail (for oil/products) which is less efficient and safe, or gas is bought from elsewhere, or dirtier hydrocarbons are used as a fallback.

The outcome of preventing natgas pipeline construction is that the natgas is still needed, but now needs to be bought from 4x more expensive liquidified natgas instead, with risks of outright shortages.

Or they burn oil for power which is dirtier and less efficient.

Meanwhile, how it's going:
We deserve everything we get, when that's how we choose to run things.

Small businesses feel real. Corporations that are still led by their founders or strong long-term figures sometimes feel real.

But the typical corporation is a faceless thing. Executives maximize intermediate-term value for shareholders that are asked to not pay attention.

To capture methane that would otherwise leak into the atmosphere, and use it as an energy source economically (turn into CO2) is net-negative for emissions because methane is more a potent greenhouse gas than CO2.
https://t.co/PJXhP1VzmS

The problem is that for many sites, it's just not economic to capture it or use it productively for other use cases.

Some source of energy demand would have to be small, nimble, and remote enough to make use of it in these various smaller and more challenging sites.

Methane (an energy source, and a more potent greenhouse gas than C02) leaks out of landfills all over the place.

Sometimes, it is be captured and used, but often not. 

Other times, it just leaks out as methane or is flared into CO2 as a mitigation (uneconomically lit on fire).

To arrive at Truth is to compare a view, with alternative views, in detail, and see how it holds.

My reason for having read world religious texts is not really about understanding the divine, but rather understanding humans, and what they think the divine is. That human search for meaning.

To understand the intrinsic desires and fears and understandings, across cultures.

Most people just work a given job, and take for granted that the religion of the region they were born with, is true.

Often they are adamant that it's true, as tho people in other cultures must be clueless.

It seems normal until you travel and see that many places think this.

Most people haven't read the Pali Canon or the Tao Te Ching.

They haven't read the Mukhya Upanishads, the Christian apocrypha, or other top-20 religious texts in the world.

Most are just born with their view and accept it, like tribes. And they take this for absolute Truth.

This applies to the majority of people in the world. 

Most people in Christian countries have never read the Qur'an.

Most people in Muslim countries have never read the Bible or studied the Christian perspective.

Most people outside of India haven't read the Bhagavad Gita.

It doesn't cross their mind that they might be incomplete. Each one believes they are the ones that are true.

Having traveled in many areas, it is fascinating how many people believe that their culture has been given absolute truth, and other cultures are lacking.

Like, imagine only understanding the religion that is associated with your geography and ethnicity, but by default assuming it's correct and that the rest of the world is utterly clueless of this supposed truth.

Most people do this.

There are people who, despite never having once read a foreign religious text, are strongly adhered to their religion of birth. Just out of geographic chance of birth.

Suggestion: Read all major texts. Understand them, their worldviews, and come to your own conclusions.

https://t.co/MSdPkrmzQQ https://t.co/bTYNZtGUc1
Demand destruction is starting to kick in to break the European power price spike.

Protecting the environment is important; it's part of protecting property.

But it has to be done intelligently, realistically, with engineering input, with the right tech and investment.

Otherwise it backfires, neither being good for the environment or for people.

Hydrocarbon usage can be reduced (not eliminated) by making use of nuclear baseload.

Plus if an area has enough nuclear power surplus, then tech like hydrogen can perhaps become more interesting at some point, as another way to store energy for transportation.

For the foreseeable future, it will still be important to have hydrocarbons.

Some are cleaner than others. Some can have their CO2 emissions partially captured. They provide redundancy, safety, and a way to store energy apart from the grid. And for materials of course.

This is why nuclear is an important (and still under-appreciated) energy source. Reliable baseload power, and cleaner than alternatives. A country can store a big stockpile of fuel, too.

But even then, droughts can affect river levels and nuclear cooling. Diversification!

In addition to being inflationary and bad for productivity if grid deficiencies occur with high EV penetration, too much energy centralization (100% reliant on grid) can lead to significant natural disaster risks and loss of emergency response capability.
https://t.co/dtOpeIRTmF

Electrical grid infrastructure in the US and many other countries is aging. Imagine using policies to accelerate or mandate EV usage, and then not also investing heavily in the grid, to have the best grid possible?

Guaranteed failure if that combo happens.

In other words, all of the current gasoline energy throughput that is distributed via pipelines and trucks and other means, has to be added to the exiting electrical grid throughput, in a theoretical high-EV penetration scenario.

Almost nobody is planning for that.

If a country/state is meant to have almost all EV penetration, then among other issues, the grid better be rock solid. Because the redundancies are gone at that point. 

Blackouts = no electricity = no transport.
https://t.co/2tN9XDangk

If policymakers mess this up by putting policy before tech, then ironically they end up taking two steps forward and five steps back.

They end up falling back on emergency use of coal, and their public eventually grows tired of such unreliable power and inflation.

That includes production, transmission, distribution, and storage. Cheaply and reliably.

And if a country's policymakers instead try to de-growth and stagnate intentionally, it just means they cede power to other countries instead, and deal with rising populism domestically.

During an energy transition of any sort, if policy directives front-run what is currently technically feasible, then it leads to energy shortages.

For an energy transition to work, the tech has to be right. It has to be obvious enough that people want that tech, and it works.

Other times, the idea is more inherently unworkable due to unaligned or unrealistic incentives and lack of fitness to exist in reality.

In this case, it is deep human nature or physical reality that renders the idea unworkable.

Basically, can the idea pass the "Handey test"?

Sometimes, a new technology could make a prior unworkable idea become suddenly workable. It provides the missing piece.

Maybe for example the printing press and widespread literacy, is what is needed for the previously unworkable idea to flourish.

Whenever people propose some idyllic philosophy or political outlook, that is the quote I think of.

If your proposed idea exists nowhere in the world, then you should question the fitness of the idea- what shortcoming does it have that has stopped it from existing?

@DzambhalaHODL @bitcoinmac 1) There is almost always some background fiscal, because most countries run structural deficits, partially financed by central banks once they reach a certain point.

2) Taking collateral off the market pushes some pools of capital into other assets.

@bitcoinmac @DzambhalaHODL Suppose Treasury wants to give people $4 trillion in helicopter money, all combined.

They go to issue all the bonds to pay for this, but primary dealers don't have enough capacity to buy most of that issuance in that period of time. Market goes illiquid.

@bitcoinmac @DzambhalaHODL Most money in the economy is not physical; most of it is the money we have in our checking and savings accounts. Fiscal expenditure mainly winds up in the economy via spendable bank deposits (checking and savings accounts).

@bitcoinmac @DzambhalaHODL Reserves don‚Äôt get drawn down and pushed into the economy.

Reserves are basically the historical record of the cumulative fiscal expenditure that was pushed into the economy but not withdrawn anywhere from it (and instead just created).

@DzambhalaHODL By definition, because reserves are part of their liabilities.

When the Fed does QE, it simultaneously increases its assets and liabilities. If done alone, it's mostly just relevant for asset prices, not CPI. If combined with a lot of fiscal expenditure, then CPI üöÄ.

@DzambhalaHODL @bitcoinmac Yes, but they mainly enter via the fiscal channel.

If the Treasury sends everyone $5k, issues a bunch of bonds, and the Fed creates new bank reserves to buy those bonds, then that money enters M2, and is spendable, and was borrowed from no private sector entity.

@DzambhalaHODL The Fed buys on the secondary market, not directly from the fiscal authority.

Any time the Fed expands its assets (UST and MBS mainly), it does so by increasing its liabilities (reserves mainly, but also TGA and/or physical currency since they are convertible).

@DzambhalaHODL Reserves can be converted to physical currency via the Fed, if a bank needs some of that.

Banks generally maintain pretty low physical cash levels though (just enough for ATMs, some withdraws, etc).

In the early decades of the internet, when end-to-end encryption was developed, it was controversial. "Who would want privacy online, other than bad people!?"

But of course this technology became a key pillar of safe online credit card payments. We all use it now.

However, they are also used by hackers and money launderers, which is what agencies use as justification to go after the services/tech.

Agencies generally don't like the idea of physical cash or private digital equivalents, and would prefer the ability to see into all dealings.

People use crypto privacy techniques in large part to stop exchanges/corporations/others from spying on their subsequent transactions.

They are also used by human rights groups in authoritarian parts of the world.

In addition to going after operators of mixers, agencies are going after developers that wrote the code, for having invented something that made it possible.

New details and connections could come to light in this particular case, but it is a concerning development either way.

@GeminiHoopz In what way?

US broad money supply has been flat year-to-date.

It's the longest stretch of non-growth in the broad money supply since mid-2009, and before that, mid-2003. https://t.co/EFSB73Z4Gv

For example, the US Bank Secrecy Act of 1970 made banks file gov reports on transactions/deposits over $10k (which was worth the equivalent of $80k today).

By never changing the threshold while dollars became worth 1/8th of what they used to, they broadened the scope by 8x.

Due to ongoing inflation, the thresholds naturally shrink over time, too.

If you just leave the cap in place for a long enough time as currency devalues over years and decades, it effectively keeps lowering the cap on what you can use physical cash for.

The argument they use in favor of it is that it makes it harder for organized crime to move value around.

The argument against it is that it reduces privacy of normal people too, and gives governments+banks more power to block transactions they don't like (even if not illegal).

Israel is tightening their ban on using physical cash above certain thresholds, including between private citizens.

I think this trend will probably continue to other countries over time.

Financial analysts that are unfamiliar with digital assets and specifically the bitcoin network, as it relates to peer-to-peer networks, are probably missing out.

It's a huge space, worthy of analysis.

I'm bullish with a 5-10 year view.

Bitcoin as a slice in a diversified investment portfolio is useful, but not my primary interest. 

The work that people like @gladstein and @odell and @starkness and @adam3us and @JeffBooth and @nvk and @jack and countless others are doing is far more interesting than investing.

The biggest global markets are money and real estate. Not art or financial services or tech platforms. I happily leave those to others.

Bitcoin is relevant for money, and in a global sense the total addressable market for that is huge.

Bitcoin is like a human body. It has white blood cell defenders, and other more complex cells. Some are staunch defenders and others are thoughtful builders, but both are useful.

The main question is the state of the network.

Investors that treat bitcoin like an investment only, miss several key details.

As both an investor and a user, I want to see development in privacy and humanitarian usefulness. 

Things like privacy/scaling improvements like what @EricSirion and @obi and others are working on.

I also like to analyze ways bitcoin could fail, or how it could improve on any given layer of its stack.

Software exploits, potential transaction censorship, privacy limitations, etc.

I love the ever-critical public proponents like @brian_trollz and @nic__carter and others.

Additionally, I like the published work of many broad crypto figures. @balajis, @MarkYusko, @DTAPCAP, @dan_pantera, @nic__carter, @MikeIppolito_ .

They bring great insight and analysis to macro markets and the digital asset ecosystem.

That's not to say that there isn't any interesting software development work within other digital asset ecosystems. There is.

But in terms of decentralized layer 1 protocols as a monetary network, it's specifically bitcoin+stablecoins that I find interesting as a big macro idea.

Separately, there are plenty of great bitcoin-focused consumer-oriented or institution-focused companies. 

@NYDIG_BTC, @DigitalAssets, @SwanBitcoin, @unchainedcap, @BullBitcoin_, @river, @theamberapp and others. I'm a fan of all of these companies.

There was a period from the late 1800s to the early 2000s where this was probably technically inevitable, but now there are technical ways to improve this.

My trading/investing is about making money, but my focus is on improving life.

Money needs to be improved, globally.

The global financial system as structured favors elites, rather than most people. It doesn't benefit median Americans, median Europeans, median people in emerging markets, etc.

It benefits those near Washington DC and Frankfurt, and few others.

Most of my global macro analysis keeps pointing to the same problem: that the global monetary system is broken, limited, and doesn't work for many people.

It's a five decade old opaque system that is flailing around, and rewards the unproductive at the expense of the productive.

I'm interested in seeing the build-out of the #LightningNetwork, and various other ways to bring a better user experience to people throughout the developing world in particular.

People in the developed world should watch this (1:17 to 1:40):
https://t.co/Q4j8kOFRpH

But within the cryptocurrency asset class, after a thousand hours of analysis, I personally focus only on bitcoin there.

The companies I work strategically with, or help with venture financing on, are bitcoin-only.

Via entities like @SwanBitcoin and @egodeathcapital.

I personally invest in multiple asset classes. Domestic stocks, foreign stocks, currencies, bonds, commodities, precious metals, real estate.

I focus on the long-run, but I'm aware of cycles and agnostic about asset classes.

Not tied to anything in particular in terms of $.

When meeting them in person, you encounter various sub-worlds. That which is on Twitter is the visible part of the iceberg, while the biggest part is underwater.

Some of the biggest movers in the space barely have time for Twitter. There's almost an inverse correlation.

Broadly between the various subgroups, and perhaps a unifying cultural factor, is that the ecosystem tends to sniff out and eat hubris for lunch, while rewarding hard work and results.

The various communities happily kill egos and self-appointed leaders on a recurring basis.

Only within the bitcoin community have I seen anarchist conservative-aligned carnivores be close friends with progressive/libertarian vegans in person, and rush to get a taxi together in the rain.

There's something unique here. Something powerful. 

Modern tribes are flexible.

There are OG cypherpunks, developers, libertarians, conservatives, progressives, entrepreneurs, VCs, miners, self-styled plebs, analysts, scam breakers, etc.

Some of the biggest forces in bitcoin aren't even active on Twitter, or are anonymous.

There are loud uninformed social media individuals, and periodic waves of groupthink, but that happens in any space.

Plenty of individuals push back on that when it happens.

Truth is, there is no "bitcoin community"; it's a group of many very different sub-cultures.

Bitcoiners are a polarizing group among broader Twitter, but it's actually a great set of people for the most part when you get to know the ecosystem and the various individuals, imo.

Disagreeable in aggregate, perhaps. But principled.

Each day that Europeans spend this much money on natgas/power prices, and each day that Americans pay high gasoline prices and food prices and so forth, builds over time towards nonlinear financial and geopolitical problems.

A friend of mine recently described this as the "area under the curve" meaning that it's not just the level of energy prices that matters, but also the duration of high energy prices.

For nerds: it's the integral of energy prices over time that really matters.

I think one thing investors currently fail to realize is that energy prices, even if they merely stay at their current levels in a choppy sideways band, have massive implications for households around the world.

I mentioned this monetary example on my recent podcast with @stig_brodersen as well:
https://t.co/Mb1x1Hwvfb

https://t.co/SfjgmL67MV

Money is not just an arbitrary "shared delusion" as some people say, because unless the money is inherently scarce, people who don't share the delusion can exploit those who do, by making more of it. 

In other words, a money's properties do matter.

This flawed money eventually went out of use around the time of the revolution, with different colonies having somewhat different timings for that.

The 1792 Coinage Act then created the US dollar, and a coinage system based around precious metals.

In response to this quality difference (imperfect fungibility), tobacco would then be graded and held in warehouses with notes issued against it.

So at that point they introduced counterparty risk on top of an inflationary commodity money, while trying to suppress new supply.

The government then had to impose various restrictions on how much can be planted, which groups of people are disallowed from planting it, etc.

Also, due to Gresham's law, people circulated their lower-quality tobacco domestically and sold the high-quality tobacco overseas.

As tobacco acquired a monetary premium, of course everyone had an incentive to plant more of it, resulting in dramatic tobacco inflation.

It's not very scarce, and as such it does not maintain a high stock-to-flow ratio against human technology, unlike say gold for example.

In a few pre-revolution colonies, such as Virginia, tobacco was used as money and made legal tender.

This ended up being an accelerated example of why some things are inherently unsuitable as money.

Third biggest decline was briefly in 1940 to 1941, only about 8% down and recovered to prior highs by 1943.

It's remarkable 1) how rare national housing price declines are and 2) how bad it is when it happens.

It's because of how leveraged the system is and how key housing is.

There were two times in the past century where US nationwide home prices fell a double digit % in nominal terms.

First: 1928-1933 ~26% down 
(recover to prior highs by 1943)

Second: 2006-2012 ~26% down 
(recover to prior highs by 2017)

All other periods flattish or up. https://t.co/VlyUhPrWoi

I have a diversified investment portfolio. Stocks, cash, bonds, gold, real estate, commodities, bitcoin.

Bitcoin is the only one that I think could make a serious difference. Nobody else has a credible answer to the current global monetary problems.

It's a Boolean outcome.

The global monetary system has been broken for decades. Ask anyone from emerging markets. Developed countries push volatility onto them. And human rights battles are in large part about the freedom to transact.

Censorship-resistant money is important to people. Don't dismiss it.

Lots of bucket shops use bitcoin as collateral as they make their various altcoin/scammy crypto bets. If those bets fail, they need to liquidate bitcoin.

No Fed bailouts, no wash rule, no protector is there. Only true market pricing.

Yet bitcoin is still here.

But if bitcoin *doesn't* fail, and continues to maintain key crypto market share, then watch out.

Money is a zero-sum contest. Only the deepest, most liquid, most fungible, most portable, most un-censorable, and most resistant to debasement survive.

Bitcoin is leading there.

Yield curve control is one of those things that, if implemented, a central bank has to get right on the first try. 

Because otherwise, they make it way harder to do a second time.

However, if the market thinks the BOJ might eventually blink at the cost of defending their 0.25% cap, then the BOJ is likely in a world of hurt.

This is because once the BOJ gives up a yield cap and moves it, there is little reason for the market to trust that new cap either.

Now they face a dilemma. 

The BOJ *can* submerge the yield back below 0.25% again, by consistently re-iterating and showing up with their unlimited bid for JGBs day after day, but at the cost of continually crushing the yen.
The Bank of Japan is working hard to defend its 0.25% 10-year bond yield cap, which they backstop with an unlimited bid to buy bonds at that cap. https://t.co/nNkE0mtBWx

@Amangrewal1000 Yep, it remains the best decade to learn from.

People unfamiliar with that decade have been shocked.

When velocity is *collapsing* in a bust, inflation doesn't happen. Utter demand destruction.

But when velocity stabilizes and goes sideways as money supply expands, inflation can absolutely occur. 

In fact, those are the environments where inflation has historically occurred.

People argued, incorrectly, that you can't get inflation without higher velocity.

Not true. 

The 1970s did not have higher velocity than the 1960s, for example, and yet inflation was vastly higher.

There's very little actual correlation between velocity and inflation.

I continue to get questions about monetary velocity.

Outside of acute deflationary busts, velocity has almost no correlation with price inflation during a 150+ year period across multiple countries. 

I pointed this out to people since prior to the current inflationary spike.

@dylnbrnt It's not about bank reserves. It's about broad money.

When higher and higher debt/GDP is offset by lower and lower interest rates, and debt servicing costs relative to income move structurally down.

When the zero bound is hit, a commodity capex cycle comes, and interest rates start moving up, that debt/GDP level starts to matter...

This happens frequently in emerging markets, but hasn't happened in developed markets since the 1940s.

Economists and policymakers in developed markets often think this can't possibly be a rroblem for them.

In periods of lower debt/GDP and commodity abundance, this has been a non-issue. Bond vigilantes get scoffed at for being alarmist.

However, when debt/GDP gets high enough, interest rates hit zero and start moving up, and commodities are undersupplied, it becomes an issue.

Peer-to-peer borderless bearer asset money based on encryption, with an open network that people around the world can build on, probably opens up more possibilities than most of us have thought about yet.

Technology tends to do that, but it usually seems impractical at first.

Now, we once again have money that moves as quickly as commerce again. Digital bearer assets.

People ask what you can do with it. Well, it's money. You can do with it what you will. It's a shared ledger in a decentralized cloud. Easy to transfer, hard to confiscate or censor.

In addition, currency can be costlessly created and used to bail out selected entities, while other entities are left to market forces.

In other words, there is arbitrage to be had by policymakers and others close to the tap, between the speed of commerce and the speed of money.

Since then, we've been in this environment where we don't use money anymore (referring to bearer assets that are not someone's liability), and instead we use currency (media of exchange that are a bank liability). 

The currency has no cost, and increases in supply more rapidly.

Basically, our commerce increasingly went over telecommunications channels. Telephone calls between banks, and then over the internet.

But our money (gold) still had to move physically. So we had to use paper/digital claims on it instead, and then ultimately left it behind.

Historically, commerce and money traveled at about the same speed.

For the past ~150 years, the speed of commerce increased thanks to technology, but our money (gold) was still slow, so we had to abstract it to keep up.

Only recently has the speed of money caught back up.

@Coinman0071 Some of them do use Tether. Stablecoins are similarly useful for this purpose. 

But:
-Dollars devalue over time. 
-Tether is centralized, its collateral must be trusted, and it can blacklist certain addresses.

It's like having money in the cloud, except even the cloud provider can't close the account, because the cloud provider is decentralized.

So anyone with internet access can memorize a seed phrase, travel globally, and be able to access their coins, or transfer them to others.

Basically, bitcoin is a tool.

Like how a VPN can make it easier to send and receive information in hostile computer networks, bitcoin can make it easier to send, receive, or store value in hostile financial networks.

Some people need and understand those tools more than others.

Many people here (@OsloFF) told me how they don't use bank accounts in their countries, due to them having been seized or frozen in the past.

Or they held dollar accounts there to protect against local currency hyperinflation, but those dollars were confiscated.

Democracy activist @Farida_N, in exile from Togo, described how it's hard for the Togolese diaspora to send money to friends and family back in Togo. The money is often seized in banks. So, they often had to smuggle physical cash. 

Bitcoin is now making it easier for them.

Mauricio (@cryptonomista) from Venezuela explained how he mined bitcoins, and then used the confiscation-resistant, self-custodial, and portable attributes of the bitcoin he mined, to preserve value and leave Venezuela.

Couldn't do that with gold, fiat, stocks, or real estate.

For example, @ireaderinokun from Nigeria, of the Feminist Coalition there, described in Norway‚Äôs parliament yesterday how their bank accounts were frozen for protesting police violence, and how bitcoin was used to keep operating despite of that.

@BitcoinDobby It costs something everywhere. The question is who pays it.

I'm referring to the hospital costs. In the US, a lot of it is covered by insurance, and ultimately by insurance premiums.

Maternal death % declined rapidly in the 1800s and early 1900s from better tech. By the 1950s it was already pretty low. 

It then got gradually lower through the late 1980s, and since then has been *climbing* (including worse in the period after this chart). https://t.co/pDG051OH1I

So in rough numbers, the cost to give birth in nominal dollars is over 100x as expensive as it was in the 1950s.

Adjusted for CPI it's more like 10x as expensive (meaning birthing costs went up 10x faster than CPI).

But the statistical outcome is maybe 5x better as well.

Adjusted for official CPI $107 is something like $1,100 today. In comparison, the actual current cost to give typical birth is over 10x higher than that.

Meanwhile, infant mortality is also 80% lower today (down from like 2.5% to 0.5%).

Developed countries find themselves with labor shortages, a mismatched pool of skills available and skills needed, and a mismatched view between employers and employees regarding market-clearing wages (because the cost of living is increasing quickly).

The mix of aging developed markets, infinite developing market labor, and abundant commodities, was very disinflationary.

As two of those variables turn around (lack of commodity capex, breakdown of global order and supply chain efficiency), those add back some inflation.

For the past 2-3 decades, it has *not* been a closed system. The aging developed markets increasingly relied on 1) rapid globalization as China and eastern Europe entered the global labor market and 2) oversupplied commodities due to shale increase and EM slowdowns. https://t.co/tMs4nW7E62

However, an aged society also has a much lower ratio of workers to retirees. That means less labor to fulfill all of society's needs, creating scarcity.

That's potentially inflationary, in a closed system.

The demand-side argument is this. People consume the most resources during mid-life, as they are forming a household, raising children, etc. As they enter senior years, they tend to consume less. 

An aged society therefore has less overall demand for most goods (ex healthcare).

People often say that aging demographics are disinflationary, but that's not necessarily the case.

This is because not only is the demand side impacted by demographics, but also the supply side.

Asset prices and GDP estimates get weird, therefore, until a pivot occurs.

Due to Fed mandates (control inflation at the cost of employment), the pivot occurs only when something in financial markets breaks.

So, things get bad -> things break -> policy reversal.

To quantify it, if US debt is $30 trillion and US weighted average cost of capital reaches as high as 3%, then the federal interest expense alone would be $900 billion. Adding the deficit angle gets to well over $1 trillion that needs financing each year.

Consumer spending is over 2/3rds of US GDP, and is concentrated within the top 10%.

If house prices, stock prices, and so forth go down, it means the 10% people will be more cautious with spending, aka consumerist GDP weakens.

If most assets go down, US tax income suffers, and deficit widens. More Treasuries issued.

If foreigners aren't aggressively buying Treasuries, it means the Fed or someone has to buy them. If private sector buys them, it is in place of equities. If Fed buys them, it's a pivot.

The US banned gold ownership for decades. It was illegal to own a benign yellow metal.

They couldn't really enforce it in practice, but they used big penalties which were barely used.

Can the US ban the sharing of certain information?

What Turkey did is harder to do in jurisdictions that have more division of governments powers, various competing interests, Constitutional protections on certain things, and so forth. 

It's also hard to enforce, including in Turkey. It's at the consumer layer.

Turkey banned crypto for payments (not for holding/investing) last year.

With a failing currency and 60% inflation, they basically said that you have to use that failing currency to transact, rather than other forms of information.
https://t.co/kEY770NBK3

Encryption and software have a legal precedent in several developed countries of being considered speech. Code is language.

That obviously gets messier now that encryption and software can be used as a form of liquid bearer-asset recognized money.

Bitcoin and many cryptocurrencies are basically just a sophisticated way of people updating a big decentralized Google Spreadsheet with each other.

To prevent that from happening is challenging from a legal perspective, outside of authoritarian regimes.

This is further complicated by the fact that other than stablecoins, cryptocurrencies aren't directly linked to currency.

So if you send bitcoins to someone, you are just participating in an open source public ledger that officially isn't currency. It's just information, speech.

And the technology is open source, too.

Basically, if governments want to prevent it, they now have to do so on the consumer layer, rather than merely the banking layer.

The number of enforcement points to do that is many orders of magnitude larger. The whole population.

@woonomic Solar and wind infrastructure requires a lot of dense fuel to build.

One way to think about it is that it takes some current dense fuel, and then invests it for a low-but-positive multiple over a multi-decade period, which is good up to a certain percentage of the grid.

@woonomic If a source generates electricity at the wrong time vs demand, the price they can sell it for can be negative. Adding storage adds costs and worsens EROI.

In some areas and for some percentage of the grid, solar is of course great. Especially with a flexible load.

@woonomic Dense forms of energy with high EROI let nature do the work.

For example, oil is concentrated solar from long ago. Or, hydro takes energy from the sun (weather/rain) and then lets geography+gravity collect it over a wide area into a concentrated harvest site (big running river).

@honest_math Biomass -> Coal -> Oil -> Uranium. 

Higher and higher energy return on investment (the multiple of energy you get from the energy you need to put into getting it out).

@kineyDE Germany and Japan are somewhat outliers and kept a lot of high-end manufacturing, but a lot of the cheap energy-intensive things that Germans buy are also made in Asia.

-Close US factory.

-American per-capita energy usage looks like it went down, but really no.

If we stop tapping into denser sources of energy, and stop increasing global per-capita energy usage, then we should expect persistent inflation and scarcity in more areas.

That's the cost.

People often say that the long arc of history is disinflationary. We get occasional big inflationary decades, but for the most part, things get more efficient over time.

But that trend mainly coincides with humans tapping into denser and denser forms of energy.

BTC-denominated Lightning capacity went up 3.5x since January 2021 from a small base. Integrations from several exchanges and payment services since then too. Adopted as legal tender by a small country.

We're 1/4th of the way to my five-year view on this.
https://t.co/3ojHnqoHKV

And then when you add fiat-to-BTC-to-fiat payments over Lightning, it gets even more interesting because it doesn't necessarily need to be a taxable event. 

Lightning wallets with a BTC balance and a USD/stablecoin balance.

Lower fees than Visa and others.

I don't want to spend my BTC either (yet), but the mere fact that it's directly or indirectly accepted by more vendors in more countries, makes that BTC more useful to own, and increases the network's practical permissionless payment capability.

There are now plenty of vendors that make this easy for merchants to implement, and the merchant can still receive dollars if they want (rather than BTC), or can decide their % split.

Since it's an open network, anyone can build on it, globally.

This is because, if all you can do with BTC is convert it back into fiat on a major exchange, then it's easy to isolate it, effectively blacklist addresses, etc.

But if you can directly spend it on goods and services across companies and jurisdictions, it's harder to isolate.

Some people naturally dismiss this because they don't want to spend their BTC; they want to save it.

However, the more places that accepted BTC at point of sale (on-chain or Lightning or otherwise), the more permissionless the whole network is.

If you have a flexible load that can tolerate high variability and/or remote locations, it becomes one of the few things that is able to pay a positive rate for that stranded power.

By extension, such a load improves the economics of highly-variable sources of power.

Power is not completely fungible.

Due to fluctuating demand and fluctuating supply, there is not a perfect match. As such, power frequently has a negative price.

@here_tolearn Well that is the million dollar question but it starts with specifically making sure you understand the strongest counter-arguments to any idea you hold.

Always ask, "where would a smart person of the opposite view disagree with me on this?"

To avoid being caught offsides as an investor, policymaker, or just in your own life, researching money and energy, and frequently re-assessing your own beliefs and understandings on those subjects, will be important.

There's always more to learn.

During times of abundance, worldviews don‚Äôt get tested very strongly and people are shielded from the consequences of being inaccurate.

It‚Äôs during the times of scarcity that reality reasserts itself and filters out the workable from the unworkable worldviews.

The 2020s decade is shaping up to challenge a lot of worldviews on money and energy.

Like, if someone is wrong in their view about the properties of money or energy, the consequences for that will be big. This is true both on the personal level and national level.

The battle of the yield curves rages on.

Over time, we should expect trade costs for most things to trend toward zero.

The exception is for giant settlement transactions or long duration positions, where quality assurances matter for everything, and even then only a tiny % of the settlement value in fees makes sense.

Scaling challenges can present a negative network effect for DeFi. It becomes about scale and efficiency, which are often at odds with decentralization and security.

That's the long-term challenge for smart contract platforms in general; they're competing as tech middle-men.

In any industry, analogue or digital, one must ask what the economic moat is.

If there's no moat, then the service becomes mostly commoditized, with users continually seeking out the lowest fees and smoothest experience.

Art NFTs are lower velocity than DeFi, and so there has been somewhat less fee/scaling pressure to hop across chains. Ethereum still maintains huge market share there.

As OpenSea adds other chains, maybe the NFT market share will open up more too?
