When the pandemic hit in 2020, governments printed trillions of dollars. Investors were shocked, but historians were not really.

Governments did so because they were so financially and socially leveraged, that they couldn't just take a shock and move on. Too leveraged for that.

But in times of unusually high wealth concentration, strong political polarization, culture wars, and decaying institutions, people have a much lower threshold for hitting a breaking point, protesting, becoming extreme, etc.

Besides financial leverage, one must also consider social leverage.

In times of relative political unity and a strong social contract, people are willing to go through hardship and sacrifice, viewing it as being in this together. https://t.co/IRFENtACqr

But such a high-leverage system blows up if it encounters those recessionary and/or high rate conditions.

The result is usually currency devaluation, stagflation, like an emerging market recession rather than a typical developed market recession.
https://t.co/3blzgAv1s9

In a low-leverage system, high commodity prices can result in recessionary conditions, higher interest rates, and thus less demand. The demand side shrinks to match the tight supply side.

Meanwhile, new capital is incentivized to come in and bring new commodity supply to market.

Households and companies then have trouble serving their debts, and those creditors then have trouble paying their own debts, etc. 

Employment slows, tax revenue falls, sovereign deficits widen and get monetized by the central bank, etc.

A low-leverage system can take shocks. For example, a solid business with little/no debt can have its cash flows go up and down based on economic conditions, without blowing up. 

Up years are fun, down years aren't, but it's okay either way.

The modern financial system is based on the premise of constant (and relatively smooth) growth indefinitely, including persistent credit growth. 

War and commodity shortages threaten the whole model.

Back in 1994, the curves diverged significantly too (and that was the start of a Fed hiking cycle, but not a recession). 

The 10-2 led in that instance, and the 10-3 curve followed as the Fed hiked rates. But there was no inversion; a Pyrrhic victory at best for the 10-2. https://t.co/EAItId7Aeb

Meanwhile, due to multi-decade high inflation along with various measures of financial repression and a literal war occurring along with acute commodity challenges that are not yet fully understood, either yield curve could be significantly off.

In plain English, the 10-3 curve is saying "no recession in clear sight" while the 10-2 curve is saying, "we're probably getting close to a possible recession, but not confirmed, and probably many months away, but asset prices start to top around here."

The 10 year - 2 year yield curve currently has historic negative divergence from the 10 year - 3 month yield curve.

The 10-3 curve has a slightly better track record and is the original academic study. Meanwhile, the 10-2 curve is more market-oriented. So, a point in both camps.

@sattarn @JanGold_ @JordanEliseo If people use the wrong ledger to keep track of debts (e.g. one that is too easy to debase, dilute defraud, edit, and so forth), then they get arbitraged out of that illusion over time.

The things that stuck around as money for the long run were not luck, but their properties.

@JanGold_ @JordanEliseo e.g. if bitcoin wins over dogecoin (as I expect it will), it's not based on luck. It's based on the different properties of those monies.

@JanGold_ @JordanEliseo If people believe in bitcoin but it is not hard enough (based on its security, network effect, scarcity, etc), then ultimately that belief would be misplaced.

@PeterMillenial Governments can control on/off ramps in their own jurisdictions. Not other jurisdictions.

Governments can't "turn off" the open source lightning network.

Thus, bitcoin and cryptocurrencies aren't really about "avoiding the law" but rather are about putting the onus on governments to act within the law, and giving individuals more mobility options when governments begin to change the law in a way that trends away from liberty.

It's not a "right or left" issue, because one merely needs to imagine their least-favorite politician winning the next election, or two or three elections from now.

Most people are in favor of rule of law, but the questions are "which law?" and "in which order?"

Custodial money often can't be withdrawn from a jurisdiction if for whatever reason rule of law breaks down there. 

Self-custodial money can be withdrawn from a jurisdiction if the individual is able to move their self elsewhere (and sometimes, even if they can't).

Custodial financial services allow governments to freeze accounts first, and then sort out who is guilty or innocent later.

Self-custodial financial services force governments to actually charge people with a crime before they can use pressure to freeze their accounts.

We have to be open to the possibility of major macro regime shifts, technological disruption, and significant changes to the Overton window.

For example, the prior fourth turning was the 1930s/1940s. The current one is 2010s/2020s (roughly).

Various macro shifts, monetary system resets, and so forth are there. No wonder existing institutions break down. Quantifying things is helpful. https://t.co/nyd0rF19F1

Generational theory itself seems too qualitative, too "voodoo". A common criticism.

As someone who thinks quantitively, the breakthrough for me was realizing that all of their "Fourth Turnings" (where institutions get challenged and rebuilt) align with long-term debt cycles.

Basically, social contracts and institutions inevitably suffer from entropy. What gets built, eventually decays and gets corrupted.

After many decades, new generations push back against those institutions, and build the next cycle of institutions to replace them.

It helps to be familiar with generational theory and Fourth Turning type stuff in this macro environment. 
https://t.co/Iqe59UpCWN

It contextualizes things that seem "unprecedented", because much of this happened 80-100 years ago.

@ChrisMcCown @biancoresearch There are not many market participants that consider the possibility that inflation might be structural *and* the Fed won't meaningfully fight it.

In summary, there's a difference between artificial/centralized scarcity and *true* scarcity that exists apart from human decisions.

It's similar to the difference between money/property and equity securities.

As an equity investor, I like securities. They're just not gold/BTC.

There's a reason that bitcoiners have the most aggressive dollar-cost-averaging community.

They correctly identify work and true scarcity, and understand it. It's hard to rival that force and utility of something that *can't* be increased in supply.

For gold, we have no ability to increase its inflation rate even when we want to. Maybe ocean floor or asteroid mining eventually, but who knows.

For BTC, it's capped at 21M. Maybe quantum or similar existential threat in the future could rally the community behind a hard fork.

Bitcoin, because it's actually decentralized, has no ability to *decide* to increase or decrease its distribution of coins. There's no "Bitcoin Foundation". 

It's a commodity.

The hard cap is 21M. If people change the rules and hard fork, they create a separate currency.

Ethereum's focus on being "ultrasound" literally makes me less bullish, not more bullish, despite the fact that Ethereum is the only crypto network effect that rivals Bitcoin.

IMO: Focus on being the best smart contract blockchain, or you'll likely fail. You're not "ultrasound".

Ethereans, before you get mad at me or call me biased, I have a longform article outlining my view on smart contract blockchains.

I analyze them seriously, as securities. I analyze stocks, commodities, digital assets, bonds, etc.
https://t.co/DlE7VRW7ao

https://t.co/9hYwWmlwh2

In other words, assets that compete for artificial scarcity have to compete against hundreds of companies w/ revenue that do share buybacks, including big ones like $AAPL with $2T+ market cap.

Realistically, securities only compete on the quality of their network/product.

If we judge managed fiat/corporate currencies based on their human-decided inflation/deflation rate, Ethereum is something like #100 in line for deflationary currencies.

You're talking about +/- 1% per year? 

I'm like, "Son, get 100th in line behind Apple at -5%"

That's why, for thousands of years, gold was money. We literally don't know how to acquire it at a faster rate.

Only brief exceptions exist, where we discovered a new continent and harvested easy deposits from that (and/or killed/conquered existing harvesters for theirs).

However, sound money doesn't refer to the *decision* to deflate a currency.

It refers to the *inability* to inflate a currency.

For example, over a century despite occasional 10x increases in the price of gold, we *can't* make more than 2% of it per year. 

Chart via @NYDIG_BTC https://t.co/tspjgUcubA

Ethereum proponents describe their currency as "ultra sound" as a marketing term because it now has low inflation, and possibly deflation. Lower even than #bitcoin, at least on the surface.

https://t.co/tS9csZlheM

My concern, in the long run, is that a variety of policies and challenges will eventually cause $AAPL price to flatline.

At the end of the day, it's participating in a highly competitive industry, and its monopoly-like effects are fragile.

But that's best saved for another day.

In exchange for this decision, $AAPL shareholders take on more volatility, and tie themselves to the success or failure of 150,000 employees to make good products.

It's like investing in the currency of a small country, with close ties to the US and China. 

Network effect.

In other words, investors ask themselves, "would I rather hold dollars that are currently increasing by 12% per year in quantity and yield sub-0.50%, or hold $AAPL shares, for which there is less each year and also yield about 0.50%?"

Apple shares peaked at ~26M, now at ~16M.

Shares of Apple stock are a deflationary asset; the number of units continues to decrease over time.

During disinflationary decades, inventory is basically a liability. Asset-light businesses with higher ROIC do well. 

During inflationary decades, inventory is an appreciating asset. Asset-heavy businesses with lower ROIC tend to have their time in the sun.

@bizktm They are mean reverting during disinflationary decades and then generally have massive stepwise increases to new plateaus during inflationary decades, from which point they resume a mean-reversion trend around that much higher level.

During those (and prior) inflationary decades, value stocks as a group have outperformed growth stocks as a group.

That's partly because commodity producers are generally classified as value stocks, but also because growth stocks tend to have their high valuations reduced.

As a general rule, stocks outperform commodities over the long run because they are able to compound and grow. 

However, during inflationary decades (such as the 1970s and 2000s), stocks tend to underperform commodities. https://t.co/veUUn2NOFZ

@sameebtc Those aren't reversed.

@tonipnd Yes, referring to an operation that uses electricity but has a lot of flexibility for when they use it.

For example, data centers are not very flexible (uptime is critical). Bitcoin miners are flexible (shutting off for a period of time is not a big deal).

@PhilDun94045826 Due to their unusually flexible load characteristics, bitcoin miners can tailor their electrical contracts to get cheaper power most of the time in exchange for being the first to shut off at key times, when either production drops or demand spikes. 
https://t.co/taQzlKT7ws

Fred Thiel's (@fgthiel) segment on the topic of bitcoin miners as flexible load balancers starts at 35:20. Good presentation.
https://t.co/x8UQuVwWKl

Basically, bitcoin miners use <0.14% of global energy and contribute to <0.06% of global e-waste, and yet also are one of the available tools to increase solar/wind power production as a percentage of the grid.

It's worth researching, not dismissing out of hand. Useful tech.

People in the industry are already putting this relatively rare feature of bitcoin miners (location and time flexible loading, with electricity representing a large % of business expenses) to good use. 
https://t.co/taQzlKT7ws
https://t.co/g7rSpZtvP9

This is an example of a tangible improvement and it's already starting to happen in some areas.

However, it remains poorly understood by many people because it involves the intersection of electrical grid specifics and bitcoin mining specifics.

Bitcoin miners can tailor their demand, and so can industries like hydrolysis for hydrogen production potentially.

Over time, utilities can co-locate bitcoin miners as a flexible load to increase profitability and usefulness of their intermittent power sources.

Wind power is also highly variable, and less predictable than solar. It helps to have a flexible demand load that can soak up excess power generation and put it to good use (and pay the producer for it).

For example, solar arrays generate a lot of power mid-day, and if not used at that specific time, that power is simply wasted. Those bars on the chart represent wasted energy. 

Most types of electrical demand can't tailor their demand to the time of day.

The BMC Q4 livestream had a good chart about rising power curtailment in California.

To maximize the efficiency of these power sources as they grow as a % of the grid, they need either better storage (which has lots of physical limitations at scale), or more time-flexible loads. https://t.co/cZOQVWmyd1

Intel is potentially getting into the bitcoin mining space.

If anything, pretending we are doing good to check off certain boxes as perceived by others, while still doing whatever we were doing before, slows real progress. 

One of the worst things we can do is to feel like we are doing something constructive, without actually doing so.

Most government and corporate actions are about the next election cycle, the next quarterly report, the next vesting period. Almost all short-term.

Real progress is more about long-term thinking and sustainable designs, not short-term narrative point-scoring and signaling.

It's less about what sector a company is in, and what check boxes they are ticking off, and more about whether they, at the core philosophy of their business, are emphasizing the long-term or the short-term in terms of investment and stakeholders.

We should absolutely reward companies that do good, fundamentally. That treat employees and customers well. That maximize environmental efficiency over the long run. That are aware of their limitations and echo chambers and seek diverse expertise to flourish.

And a good company over the long run takes care of its employees and clients rather than just emphasizing executives and shareholders. 

Nucor outperformed US Steel in large part because it took care of its employees through cycles, realizing how valuable they are. https://t.co/VlEmlo50WO

I'm 100% in favor of environmentalism. We should absolutely prioritize less pollutants going into the air, water, and ground.

And I'm very in favor of diverse boards of directors. A broad background of experiences is beneficial for risk management and growth opportunities.

@Bobreed774571 @AnuragOjha @MacroAlf @JeffSnider_AIP Japan has a balanced trade situation on average, unlike the US which has a structural trade deficit.

@minute_market To not use Japan as a "you can print money without causing inflation" example, as people often do.
@1PreciousBTC Japan rapidly decelerated their broad money supply growth to unusually low levels starting 25 years ago, both by their historical standards and compared to the global average.
@Velozarra Yep for decades they have done the opposite of that period. Structural corporate deleveraging instead of structural corporate credit growth.

@MacroAlf @AnuragOjha @JeffSnider_AIP Yep it's about +5%/year M2 growth from monetized fiscal deficits, and -2%/year M2 contraction from corporate debt reduction, resulting in about +3%/year M2 growth.

Japan is not the epic money printer people think it is. Their money supply grew more slowly than just about any other country over the past two decades and counting.

Corporate debt reduction offset monetized government deficits, resulting in 3% annualized broad money growth.

@AnuragOjha @MacroAlf @JeffSnider_AIP Japan has the lowest price inflation in large part because it has the slowest broad money supply growth in the world over the past 25 years. https://t.co/6XMmrhlFF5

@blueskycap1 Custody of the private keys that let you transfer it to someone else.

The ledger exists offline, with anyone who has a full node on their drive. Updates to the ledger, however, exist online, with new blocks created on average every 10 minutes.

Some bitcoin owners celebrate the network's anniversary with "Proof of Keys Day", where they take personal custody of the coins they own from exchanges.

Kind of like physical cash or gold, one of the attributes of Bitcoin is that an owner can take personal custody of it.

So in some ways, digital scarcity in the form of a distributed peer-to-peer ledger and consensus ruleset was an inevitable discovery.

However, the first successful implementation was unique in terms of its specific parameters, and thus is an invention.

The foundations of the Internet were made in the 1970s and 1980s, the consumer browser was invented in the early 1990s, proof-of-work was invented in the 1990s, and SHA-2 encryption was published in 2001. Bitcoin itself was published in 2008 and released in 2009.

Next year, Bitcoin will become half as old as "the Internet" as we know it. It seems to have some staying power, having lasted as long as it did thus far: 
https://t.co/a1Dojq6uZq

Bitcoin is 13 years old today, the anniversary of the genesis block. It's an angsty teenager now, I suppose, which actually kind of fits.

The US dollar in its current fiat form is 50 years old, born in 1971.

Bitcoin is now more than 1/4th as old as the current US dollar. https://t.co/TJxHQcQx0m

I think this is a factor that has macro implications for real rates over the long run, but that few macro investors are paying attention to yet. 

For confirmation, we'll need to see the precise details of how US stablecoin regulation shakes out.

On the institutional side, standing repo facilities increase the fungibility between Treasuries and cash. On the retail and institutional side, regulated stablecoins also increase the fungibility between Treasuries and cash.

By increasing the fungibility between cash and Treasuries as collateral for the same asset token, it broadens the type of financial repression that is possible. It's another lever to hold interest rates on government debt well below the inflation rate.

I do think that custodial stablecoins will increase as a medium of exchange in the 2020s decade. And if so, that means retail investors might increasingly hold both cash and Treasuries, rather than just cash in a bank, all wrapped up together as collateral for the stablecoins.

Stablecoins are used primarily for crypto trading but also somewhat for a medium of exchange. 

Some companies like Facebook (via Diem & Novi) are aiming to increase their usage as medium of exchange. We'll see if they are successful.

Whenever a sovereign government becomes highly indebted in its own currency, financial repression follows. 

This means that interest rates on the debt are held below the inflation rate for a long period of time, and institutions are mandated to own the debt. https://t.co/wMu7LcSnFs

USDC, GUSD, and USDP have already gone this route. 

USDT is the one that holds other types of assets as well, which are not backed by the full faith and credit of the US government. 

Entities that don't conform to regulations are basically eurodollars- offshore dollars.

Stablecoins will become increasingly regulated, only allowed to hold nominally risk-free assets, if they want to connect to regulated, legal institutions.

This includes cash and Treasuries. As such, stablecoins are a way to monetize Treasuries.

Apart from conscious lifestyle choices (get outside, exercise, look far away), or societal collapse that re-prioritizes physical attributes for survival, probably only a big increase in gene editing tech can address this structural trend. But then we get Gattaca type stuff.

Why do we usually envision aliens as small, frail, nearly-featureless beings?

It's because we subconsciously envision them to have so much technology that their physical form deteriorates via non-selection over time as they become entirely reliant on that technology.

Even when it comes to reproduction, things that would have harmed a person's probability of reproduction ages ago (e.g. bad eyesight -> bad hunter) become non-issues that we can correct with simple tech, and so those problems more readily carry onto later generations.

Modern society requires that we make increasingly conscious choices to go outside, get exercise, and look into the distance, so that we can get the benefits of technology without the physical and mental deterioration that often comes with it.

And then of course we had the inverse correlation between technology and depression. Hunter gathers have rather rough lives but what we think of as depression is nearly nonexistent among them. They have plenty of exercise, decent diet, and frequent flow state.

A lot of evidence shows that our lifestyles of looking at papers, screens, and phones indoors all day contributes to widespread deterioration in eyesight.

Now imagine if we work from home more, drive less, and wear VR goggles for hours a day...

@Notsmoking2 My base case is persistently negative real yields for most of the 2020s decade.

@Notsmoking2 In recent decades, it only happens during periods of time where political leaders specifically want to attract the foreign sector to buy their bonds. 

So we see periods of time where the US did that (1980s through the 2000s) and China as well.

The tactical attractiveness of bonds of course depends on timelines; there are always trading opportunities.

But it's a question of where to store capital if you don't want to trade actively and don't want it to lose purchasing power over a 5-to-10 year period.

Blue line is nominal GDP growth. Red line is 10-year Treasury yield.

Green line is their difference: 10-year yields minus nominal GDP growth.

Being overweight bonds when they don't compete with nominal GDP growth (which includes inflation), generally doesn't work out well. https://t.co/m4ZZVMrOS2

Every country that goes over 90-100% debt/GDP or so ends up with the central bank owning an increasing share of the country's sovereign debt.

The signal on those yields, at least in terms of overall magnitude, ends up telling us little about long-term forward inflation.

So the bond market is "smart money" in that it does a good job of grasping tactical acceleration/deceleration moves, but isn't smart enough to avoid 30-40% losses of purchasing power over the course of a decade on three separate occasions.

So we get big disconnects sometimes: https://t.co/3LueQ3FHVR

If you compound -4% annual inflation-adjusted returns over a decade, you lose a third of your purchasing power on consumer goods by the end of the period.

And during that period, you probably lose more than that in terms of your purchasing power of prime capital goods.

Blue line is 10-year Treasury yields. Orange line is the annualized inflation-adjusted "real" rate of return if you bought a 10-year Treasury note that year and held it until maturity. 

Bonds got killed on a real basis in all three inflationary decades (1910s, 1940s, 1970s). https://t.co/J1aATqIQEP

@dampedspring @siddiqui71 Yes it's the opposite problem of 2019. Back then there were too many T-bills; now there are not enough.

A populist movement that rallies behind a specific technology is a pretty rare and powerful concept.

@KHerriage A number of companies have been building this capability for years, with new product types, partnerships, new entrants. It's not a specific "event" in that sense.

This is a general change in market structure and if the trend continues, it affects the supply/demand balance and extends typical holding periods.

Kind of like keeping a piece of real estate permanently and refinancing it from time to time, rather than buying and flipping it.

Many North American bitcoin miners are now keeping all or most of the coins they mine on their balance sheet, and financing their expenses in other ways.

Similarly, many bitcoin hodlers use their coins as collateral for USD loans for life expenses, rather than sell their coins.

@tigeryi98 1) The rise of shale oil throughout the 2010s in the US reduced the US trade deficit. That topped out in 2020.

2) The US did massive fiscal stimulus in 2020/2021 which kept consumption high even as our exports stagnated.

In other words, what the US is primarily doing, is selling our appreciating financial assets for depreciating consumer assets. 

It's not a great trade in the long run.

I described this in my bitcoin energy article, and I was interested to hear further confirmation today that it's increasingly being looked at by large-scale utilities. 
https://t.co/onZQHbLOrr https://t.co/CAXsEiA5Ir

Bitcoin miners, unlike most other electricity consumers, can co-locate at power generators, and can easily shut off if demand reaches supply.

This strengthens the grid and makes always-on power sources more cost-effective, in lieu of efficient utility-scale battery storage.

There are always-on sources of power like nuclear, hydro, geo, and then variable power like solar/wind.

Demand fluctuates too.

During times when power supply exceeds demand, utilities need a way to profitably use that power, or they waste it. Enter co-located bitcoin mining.

The CEO of $MARA also said he believes that power companies will likely become some of the largest bitcoin miners/hosters over time. I think that's true (in addition to a healthy amount of off-grid miners).

@tmrwisyesterday More like, Aikido is a good framework to be aware of and practiced in for certain contexts, within a far more diversified and aggressive style, along with physical development.

The internet is simpler when you do the really weird and shocking trick of just like, treating it as talking with neighbors and other people in person.

Because at the end of the day, this is just a medium between people, despite illusions to the contrary.

People who absorb internet aggressions, laugh at memes, stay humble, and learn from negative comments: 

They learn from the feedback, reduce aggression, and come to understandings. People humanize them, and they humanize back.

People who get butthurt about internet aggressions, get mad at memes, have large egos, and get angry at negative comments:

They fail to learn from the feedback, and instead fuel more viral aggression against them. People dehumanize them, and they dehumanize back.

Acknowledge their concerns, ask for clarification, point out their contradictions or incorrect statements, and cheerfully defend the truth.

Maintaining aggression against that is hard.

Internet aggression is often like that: diffused if one side drops it or pulls them in.

Sometimes you can fix their perception of you and sort it out, assuming you are honest. Or if they are irrational, you give them rope to hang (embarrass) themselves.

Nothing is more awkward than attacking someone who is kind and rational in return. 

It's like verbal Aikido.

If you ignore aggressors, or acknowledge them and discuss with them, rather than insult them back, you often make progress. 

Maybe they had a bad day. Maybe they developed a false perception of you.

If you get aggressive back, it only fuels it. Instead, explore it.

Even professionals or other high-profile accounts can often go after each other aggressively.

It's often due to pent-up frustration, large egos, and dealing with other people online without the full context of their actual humanity.

People online are often weirdly aggressive, like in their basement tweeting against random avatars they don't know to support their existing worldview. 

It's better to treat it as though you are conversing with other people, because you are.

Against men tho, I found Aikido helpful.

My grappling tactic was to push them, until they push back and overpower me, at which point I quickly grab them and pull them towards me and down, dropping them off balance with their own forward momentum.

Then I choked them out.

Due to how frequently I fought larger people, for the small percentage of time when I instead fought against other women or smallish men, it suddenly felt like Goku or Rock Lee taking off his training weights.
https://t.co/xydW36qnOV

The practical problem was that my co-ed martial arts school was like 80% male, and thus basically 80% larger than me.

It's awkward leading a class of people as big or bigger than you. I was usually the smaller one in a given sparring match. An uphill battle every time.

I personally also preferred the aggressive striking style or submission style where possible. It's practical.

In my 12 yrs of fighting and a few years as an assistant instructor, I preferred striking against large opponents, and used grappling mainly against small opponents.

Aikido is admittedly kind of a shit martial art if you want to regularly win UFC. 

Investing time into some combination of kickboxing, submission grappling, and Muay Thai gets you a lot further. Offense, aggression, breaking things, with rational defense as well.

Aikido is the Japanese martial art of using your opponent's momentum against them. 

I find that it has relevance for online communication. A brief thread. https://t.co/JJDtG6fPFZ

@abbeyroad1124 Yes anything "can be" done but much like entrepreneurship, ideas are a dime a dozen but good execution is rare. 

Implementing a LN-like solution on a less solid, less decentralized base layer blockchain from scratch is something someone could try...

@abbeyroad1124 Abstracting BTC/LN for payment vs BTC the asset is mainly at the endpoints. 

In other words, someone can use fiat-to-BTC-to-fiat for international payment rails due to decent BTC liquidity in many currencies.

@abbeyroad1124 LN consists of smart contracts on the BTC base layer, and it took years to build up network effects and liquidity/usability on BTC/LN.

The LN concept can be copied to certain other blockchains as well, but they'd be starting from scratch for liquidity and network effects.

@joekelly100 Open source non-custodial lightning wallets that have nothing to do with Strike can send tips to it as well. 

Outside of Twitter, Strike can interact in both directions with those external wallets.

@Stan26873215 @aintoproudtobeg That's not how it works. 

All the Sprott fund can do is buy or sell uranium in response to market signals. It's a CEF.

If there is a premium to NAV, they have an incentive to issue shares and buy.

If there is a discount to NAV, they have an incentive to sell+buyback or hold.

@aintoproudtobeg @Stan26873215 Uranium mines take years to come into production. It's better that price discovery happens years before the lights go out, than months before the lights go out.

Just a free market decision. Sprott only does this because there is demand from investors doing the math.

@Stan26873215 @aintoproudtobeg The counterbalance is that, when uranium prices are above the cost of new production, new uranium miners can start producing. 

Remember, this isn't driving the price up to artificial levels. Uranium prices are below the cost of most new production.
Sprott's uranium fund is up 17% since this morning. https://t.co/tSIj1lWWjr
@schnauzerwauzer I think it's the best thing.

@aintoproudtobeg @Stan26873215 This is a free market. It's a private entity choosing to buy uranium, because it considers uranium to be cheap. Furthermore, they can only buy uranium if their shares trade at a premium to NAV, and thus market pricing dictates how much uranium they buy.

@Stan26873215 It benefits Sprott, and benefits the uranium producers and developers that support the utilities, to keep the lights on. 

Uranium has been below the cost of production for a long time, and so little production has come online. Higher prices are needed to get it online.
@IdeasAndAction Because they are measured from breakevens.
Sprott expanded the amount of uranium purchases they can do via share issuance.

@Peacockg Yes.

@ryancoc22 Strive to be superhuman. 

That's basically the human condition.

@electronicado86 Yes a lot of corporate media headlines are BS as well. 

Regardless of the source, big or small, it's really on the user to separate quality information from nonsense, which is hard but important.

Lots of things that were labeled conspiracy in 2020 ended up being true or likely true.

At the same time, lots of nonsense was put out as well, and keeps being put out. High noise to signal.

Large accounts seeking long-term reputations should focus on quality over quantity.

Technology and out-of-context clips make it very easy to sensationalize things.

Deep fakes, fake sound overlays, brief clips of longer things that distort what happened, etc.

Focus on quality over quantity. Take time to find the original/longer version. If you can't, skip it.

It's possible to believe these two things simultaneously: 

1) Social networks shouldn't block things for selective "misinformation". 

2) You should spend time to research a clip/headline before you share it to make sure it's legit, especially if you have a big audience.

@bitcoin_twiter Most developed countries can't afford to pay persistently positive real rates due to their high debt levels. 

Rates may rise, but unlikely into persistently positive real territory imo.

If rates stay low, then even somewhat expensive equities are better long-term bets than low-yielding cash and bonds.

@brian_trollz @bergealex4 It's possible you are underestimating how custodial some aspects will be for many people, with the option to be non-custodial.

At the end of the day, entities managing millions of accounts can settle in multiple ways between themselves. Base-layer would be prized.

@brian_trollz @bergealex4 Basically if things get that big, there would likely be multiple Liquid-like setups.  

I doubt entities would pay trillions of USD-equivalent in fees and not compress that 100-fold via layers.

@brian_trollz @bergealex4 It doesn't escape fees, but it compresses them.

If you peg BTC into L-BTC, do 100 transactions, say as settlement between entities (each one huge value), and then un-peg, you pay two big on-chain fees, but its a tiny fraction of the value of those 100 L-BTC transactions.

@brian_trollz @bergealex4 That would be a rare instance of software making an industry more expensive. Entities will likely take steps to minimize friction.

For example, one can peg-in L-BTC, do 100 transactions, and peg-out. The volume on-chain ends up being a small % of notional value in that case.

@brian_trollz @bergealex4 I take into account txn aggregation (otherwise few entities would pay $1k per transaction). The assumption is most txns would be settlement aggregates. 

So to clarify, you think that a bitcoin-based world will pay trillions of USD-equivalents in txn fees per year.

@bergealex4 That's not how it works. Bitcoin is a settlement layer; most of those txs will be on other layers. Can't do more than ~150 million txns per year, although each one can be big.

Even $1000 USD fee per base layer transaction gets you about $150 billion USD per year in annual fees.

Reserve requirements are there to prevent bank runs. Capital requirements are there to reduce the risk of bank insolvency.

However when looking at macro data sets, low bank reserves and Treasuries combined as a % of assets tend to occur prior to banking failures.

However, it also helps to check bank Treasury levels, which were also low in both periods. 

These charts for example shows the % of US bank assets held in cash and Treasuries/Agencies leading into 2008. https://t.co/JbLHCMEu2u
For example, the monetary base as a percentage of bank loans was historically low leading into the 1929 and 2008 deflationary debt crises. https://t.co/hd5eVit8vc
Historically some combination of private debt as a % of GDP, monetary base as a % of total bank loans, and the percentage of bank assets held in nominally risk-free assets, has been more predictive.

Capital ratios are of course critical for analyzing the health of a specific bank balance sheet, but historically failed to detect system issues in the bank lending sector.

That's why they were reformed post-GFC, to make them more granular.

Regulators have historically had a tough time predicting systemic bank risk ahead of time.

Bank capital ratios, for example, were not predictive of the 1929 or 2008 financial crises. Risk-weighted and raw charts: https://t.co/TewKNAXvcb

Blue line is total US household net worth in dollars, currently at $137 trillion. 

Red line is what it would be if denominated in ounces of gold, currently at 76 billion. https://t.co/bbhBwbUUTC

@BeanieBabyTrade @here_tolearn Gold was pegged to the dollar and thus artificially suppressed in the 1940s. Silver, copper, oil, real estate, stocks, were all up in the 1940s. Gold would be as well if it were not pegged.

But underneath, at the real core of things, the assets I consider money are those that produce cash-flow, or are hard monies. 

Fiat cash is a weird vehicle that cancels out debt for other people, and can spike in value temporarily (ie risk assets go down in dollar terms).

Many people view themselves as buying dips in risk assets, when they fall. I use that language as well.

In other words, if stocks or gold or bitcoin or house prices "fall" vs fiat cash, that is seen as a time to buy those risk assets, with cash being the "defensive" asset.

In previous eras, when cash/tbills yielded higher than inflation, it could serve as both savings and optionality. Now with deeply negative inflation-adjusted real yields, it serves as optionality but not savings, and thus falls into a weird category of low volatility speculation. https://t.co/QvFGkN5eqJ

In other words, I literally, without exaggeration, speculate to own some dollars (Federal Reserve liabilities) or T-bills (US Treasury liabilities), in the chance that these things will spike in value (aka "risk assets" decline in value), allowing me to buy more valuable things.

Just about every other asset I own, is something I expect to be worth more 5-10 years from now, than today. 

But fiat cash is the opposite: something that I expect to be worth less 5-10 years from now, even with interest. But I speculate on holding *some* anyway.

On the other hand, fiat cash is the only speculative asset I own, meaning the only asset I expect to decline in value over the long run but that might go up in the short run (meaning other assets temp go down in price vs fiat cash), allowing me to rebalance into those assets.
On one hand, fiat cash is a "defensive asset", with low volatility. Naturally, you need some cash to pay expenses (inevitable) and for optionality on buying other types of assets (optional).

@adam3us @TeddyVallee @MichaelRinko That is how I view it too. The more that decentralization is sacrificed for other optimizations, the more it approaches a centralized database, which are already pretty efficient. 

Databases can incorporate some blockchain technology but it's a different animal at that point.

@A_Walk_ @TeddyVallee @MichaelRinko Imo no. The legacy system runs on layers (eg Visa is a surface layer over something like Fedwire) for a reason: each layer serves a purpose and optimizes for it. 

Trying to put everything on one layer dilutes the trade-offs and optimizes for nothing in particular.

@MichaelRinko @TeddyVallee Depends on the purpose of the protocol. Global money (eg Bitcoin) or equity-like network to fill a need (eg a defi project or institutional blockchain concept).

It's less about "how many?" and more about "who can?". Basically: "Can it be done on a laptop or raspberry pi or not?"

@TeddyVallee @MichaelRinko The trade-off for protocols to have higher transaction throughput on the base layer is generally that they sacrifice decentralization. 

The bandwidth and storage to run a full node ends up requiring data center capabilities rather than single-user capabilities, centralizing it.

The reserve currency status as currently structured benefits folks like me who benefit from it without having given anything up for it.

The natural end state of this gradual shift is for international usage of the global reserve currency to diversify into usage of regional reserve currencies instead, and for countries to use more neutral bearer assets in their FX reserves.

@hema_bibani @PrestonPysh Yes in part. The foreign sector recycles persistent US trade deficits into buying US assets, increasingly including large cap tech stocks. 
https://t.co/8wrda7PrmP

Then of course after the biggest buyer vanished, add retail investors pouring into altcoins to euphoric levels,  Elon's ESG backtracking, leveraged traders getting liquidated on the correction, momentum traders stepping away, etc.

In other words, part of the run up in the second half of 2020 was due to the Grayscale neutral arbitrage trade, sucking in a ton of bitcoin. 

When ETFs and other new ways to access bitcoin made GBTC less unique, the premium went away, so the neutral arb trade went away.

Bears focusing on Tether's impact on bitcoin over the  past year would have probably done better to focus on the Grayscale neutral arbitrage trade instead.

Obviously it's different for folks in regimes that don't have freedom of speech, which is why it's worth promoting that value wherever possible, online and offline.

Ultimately, the ideal case is to combine them. To speak rather freely in public and in private, online and offline, while having enough social awareness to separate the person from their viewpoint, and to consider details of their personal experience and how they developed it.

For example, an aggressive individual with views that can harm others would get natural pushback from society. That's like an immune function.

However, if society itself gets rather corrupted, individual pushbacks towards reason are important for societal self-correction.

In person tho, folks might be too nice because all of those evolutionary social instincts kick in along with cultural norms, so they hide their true thoughts.

When one has a thought they wish to hide, it requires extra introspection. Is society weird, or is the individual weird?

Folks develop "internet enemies" that if they were to meet in person and get to know each other a bit, might be more respectful even if they naturally disagree.

Internet enemies have all the natural disagreements, without the million years of empathy instincts as social animals.

On one hand, people let out thoughts or aggressions online that they would be less prone to do in person. It helps get a feel for what people "really" think. 

On the other hand, people are social animals with instincts and bonds. Online diminishes those, leaving the rough side.

This results in an interesting question. For folks who act differently online vs offline, which one is their "true self"?

I would say a bit of both.

@Santiag78758327 There are other variables involved but in a rough sense, the ones with too much blue relative to orange are indeed always at risk of getting milkshaked, a la @SantiagoAuFund.

Countries with too much blue relative to orange are prone to currency issues. 

The other key variable to watch would be trade and/or current account balances.

If you don't learn equally from your "opponents" as your "allies", you're doing something wrong. 

And if you make disagreements personal, you're doing something wrong. 

This applies to finance, engineering, business, etc. Anything with objectively-measured results.

An investor should strive to understand and articulate the best version of the opposing viewpoint for a particular investment, which is a process known as "steelmaning", which is the opposite of a strawman fallacy. 

Understand the other side of the trade, in other words.

@buyoptions Brows money grows by loan growth and deficits. 

Demand for loans was weak, so loan growth was negative. Deficits offset that, at an average of about 5% per year.

@itsdono @adam3us @HorizonKinetics There wasn't really a crowding out effect in Japan. Most of the government debt issued was bought by the Bank of Japan with new base money. 

A lot of balance sheets in Japan went out and bought things like US Treasuries. There wasn't a lot of borrowing demand by Japanese corps.

@adam3us @HorizonKinetics After a long period of stagnation, Japanese corps improved governance, improved margins, and used some cash flows to gradually deleverage. 

They still have a lot of debt outstanding (albeit less than before), but also hold a lot of cash, so low net debt.

And the reason that Japan's broad money grew slowly (around 3% per year) was because their moderately large fiscal deficits (averaging around 5% of GDP per year) were offset by corporate debt reductions (in the ballpark of 2% of GDP per year). 

Chart via @HorizonKinetics https://t.co/Hf7BcwP7WZ

Temporary supply shortages serve as catalysts for those rapid rate-of-change inflation spikes, but then prices remain structurally higher because more money is permanently in the system. It's not *just* the supply shortage, in other words.

During the 1940s, inflation was transitory in rate-of-change terms, but after each spike in inflation, prices reached a new permanent plateau and went up from there. Cash and bondholders permanently lost purchasing power in three transitory/stepwise movements. https://t.co/LUIc0emqxQ

If we look at the money multiplier, M2/MB, along with fiscal deficits, we see further similarities between the 1930s/2010s (eras of rates hitting zero, monetary base expansion, private debt bubble peak), and 1940s/2020s (eras of fiscal dominance). 
https://t.co/a0PbU8sppA https://t.co/TiePzmoHkk

The 1940s are interesting because they are most analogous to the 2020s. After a large private debt bubble partial deleveraging (1930s and 2010s), a period of economic stagnation and external catalyst eventually resulted in a massive fiscal response (1940s and 2020s). https://t.co/OvZScwsf2e

Looking at 140 years of data, we see periods where loan growth fueled broad money growth (late 1800s, 1920s, 1950s, etc), periods where fiscal deficits fueled broad money growth (1940s), and periods like the 1970s/1980s where both lending and deficits fueled broad money growth. https://t.co/hLTJWrvvHa

Broad money growth generally occurs in one of two ways: either banks lend and create deposits (and thus increase the money multiplier, M2/MB) or when bank lending seizes up, governments run large deficits and go around the bank lending channel.

@RollyTikTok Velocity is calculated as GDP divided by M2. If M2 goes up very quickly, velocity can decrease or stay flat even if nominal GDP (including the inflationary component) goes up or sideways.

To the extent that broad money supply goes up a lot and CPI and bond yields stay relatively low, then the money tends to pile into financial assets, since it has to go somewhere. Lately that‚Äôs what the situation has been. https://t.co/nKfOnEd938

If they can do a large fiscal burst (spending without associated tax increases), and there is no big inflationary response, then the incentive exists for them to do it again. And again. And again. The only limiter would be obvious inflation.

The deflationary capacity of the current economy is huge, due to automation, software, high debt, wealth concentration, and aging demographics. 

And policymakers will be putting that deflationary force to the test.

And that‚Äôs not a criticism of policymakers in the era. For investors, there were winners and losers in that scenario depending on what asset classes they were primarily in. 

Since it was a currency devaluation, it was cash and bondholders that took the brunt of it.

In other words, if extreme fiscal policy were not occurring in the 1940s, prices would go back to normal after their brief spike from temporary shortages. 

The reason they didn‚Äôt go back to normal was because the currency itself was devalued.

The reason those 1940s price increases were not transient, is because behind the surface of commodity shortages there was a massive increase in the broad money supply due to fiscal spending, which was effectively monetized. https://t.co/LdgkM9iFNr

Some people dismiss the 1940s inflationary period as being just transient spikes of inflation due to specific temporary shortages. 

And indeed, the inflation of that era came in bursts: https://t.co/BydXUea4BR

Deflation proponents often point out that the money multiplier (broad money as a multiple of the monetary base) is low right now. That‚Äôs true. 

However, the only other time it was this low (the 1940s), was actually quite inflationary. https://t.co/Z074c9VySb

Similarly, the 2010s had a partial unwinding of a private debt bubble and a large monetary response, but limited fiscal response. 

It wasn‚Äôt until the pandemic in 2020 that policymakers brought out the fiscal cannon. https://t.co/ie4GDpHjno

During the 1930s, monetary policy hit the limit of what it can do against the prospect of a private debt bubble, and so it was then a massive fiscal response in the 1940s, forced by external factors (the war), that pumped inflation: https://t.co/vASoyw7GTM

In terms of overall fiscal and monetary policy, including the wartime-like fiscal response that we‚Äôve seen over the past year, the 2020s so far have structural similarities to the 1940s. 

Here‚Äôs the long-term debt cycle, for example: https://t.co/x4x8g5kDso

The next few years are going to test how much deflationary capacity there is in the US and global economy from technology, debt, and demographics to absorb the inflationary increase in broad money.

Lastly, a lot of energy concerns directed at Bitcoin start with the presupposition that it's useless. A trillion dollars in market cap disagrees. 

Little concern is given to worldwide washing machine energy usage, for example, because we understand the value.

@hidflect And as the price goes higher with bitcoin's halving cycles, the energy cost per market cap goes down, making it increasingly efficient.

@MichaelArouet https://t.co/PcGXivme8L

Plus, due to the incentive mechanism for miners to find cheap energy, the energy that is used for the bitcoin network is increasingly renewable or wasted/stranded energy, which is good to strive for. https://t.co/Pzrq7PxwxU

Much of the criticism around bitcoin's energy usage misinterprets the scaling mechanism and which factors affect bitcoin's total energy usage.

Buying it and driving up market cap does indirectly increase energy usage, nonlinearly.

Spending it vs holding it, however, not really.

Bitcoin's store of value aspect is what mostly drives the total energy usage of the network, since that is what mainly drives the market cap up. 

The medium-of-exchange portion of that network, if successful, is very minimal in terms of additional energy usage.

This is different from, say, making the marginal decision to fly a private jet somewhere. Your decision to fly or not fly the jet will linearly affect how much C02 gets emitted that day. 

This is not the case for deciding whether to hold or spend a bitcoin (or send an email).

And secondary layers, like Lightning, make that even more efficient, and further eliminate the additional marginal energy usage per transaction. 

The marginal decision to make a Lightning transaction has close to zero impact on anything. Like sending an email.

The only way that individual transactions on goods/services affect energy usage in the long run is by affecting the fee portion of miner revenue, but that remains a minimal part of bitcoin's energy usage. https://t.co/PVDVD5CBmr

Dividing "bitcoin's total energy usage" by "number of transactions" to determine "energy per transaction" falsely implies that your decision to spend bitcoin or hold it, linearly affects how much energy the bitcoin network uses that day, whereas it doesn't.

However, the bitcoin network can only handle a finite number of daily base layer transactions. From there, secondary layers can multiply that number arbitrarily. 

In other words, if 10x more people use bitcoin in 5 years, it won't use 10x more energy than now.

Bitcoin's overall energy usages does go up with adoption as a store of value as its market cap grows, but in a nonlinear way as it matures. It needs to be secure to function, but from there, its marginal cost per user is efficient.
https://t.co/ggW7LqEUDq https://t.co/NdnCloQY4U

Like with a company, it takes a ton of work to make a good software product (equipment, staff, time, etc). 

But then, it takes minimal work to send that software to 1,000,000,000 users compared to 10,000 users. 

High base cost for it to exist + tiny cost per marginal user.

Bitcoin's total energy usage is determined primarily from market capitalization and difficulty adjustments, not transaction volume. 

In other words, the marginal bitcoin transaction/spending choice has virtually no impact on bitcoin's total energy usage.

@travelbug8681 The normal S&P 500 is weighted by market capitalization. So for example $AAPL is much bigger allocation than $AXP. 

The equal weight version puts the same companies equally at 0.2% of the 500-member index and rebalances quarterly.

If you listen very very closely, you can hear the silent prayers of value investors all around the world wondering if the fabled "value rotation" is finally in, or just another fake-out and thus more despair. 

These growth/value rotations also tend to occur around recessions. https://t.co/F5zMcn3ZHF

The equal weight S&P 500 historically outperforms earlier in a business cycle, while the normal market weight S&P 500 historically outperforms later in a business cycle. 

Leaders in one cycle are rarely the leaders in the next cycle. https://t.co/B73z5ZKxOP

@nunya81524991 For an extreme case (not saying the US is going to that level), look at Argentina. Demographics are moderate (not that different than the US), but inflation is 40%+ due to monetary issues in particular a massive broad money supply increase.

In addition, a lot of inflation/deflation economics don't focus on the long-term commodity capex cycle. Periods of commodity oversupply can keep inflation low, and people then extrapolate linearly.

Lengthy periods of underdevelopment then lead to commodity shortages...

To put things into perspective, US population used to grow at maybe 1.5% per year, and now grows at more like 0.5% per year. That's pretty important.

Meanwhile, broad money supply is up 25% year over year, and is on track to be up 75%+ over a rolling 5-year period in the future. https://t.co/R39zMsEF1V

@siddiqui71 @EPBResearch As far as I can tell, the only solution is make more T-bills available as collateral, either because Treasury issues more, or the Fed does an operation twist and sells some T-bills to buy more T-bonds.

@EPBResearch The current plan is for little net Treasury issuance until 2H2021, due to TGA drawdown, although if they pass stimulus in March they will need to issue a bunch despite TGA drawdown. 

Should be T-bill issuance if they do.
@UkNewalchemist1 Both into m2 and reserves in this case.

@WholeGrainU238 The opposite. Treasury will spend money without issuing many bonds (since they already over-issued bonds to build up the TGA), so banks will receive deposits and have few places to put it.

Otherwise, we could see T-bill rates go lower or even mildly negative in the months ahead as T-bond rates continue to push up higher, and cause financial plumbing issues. 

Lots of moving parts here because a TGA drawdown of this size would be a first.

If Fed is proactive, they might try to do another Operation Twist, where they sell some short-end Treasuries to provide the needed collateral and buy additional long-end Treasuries, within the context of their otherwise automatic $80B/month Treasury buying plan.

But ironically now it's the opposite issue coming up. 

That's not because the short end of the Treasury market is expecting deflation as some are suggesting (quite the opposite, by most metrics), but rather it's more mechanical in nature.

For example, after the 2019 repo spike, the problem was too many t-bills vs cash. The Fed's transition from repo support to outright QE (T-bill buying) in was predictable a couple weeks in advance. 

https://t.co/LYGKjUGyIm

Despite massive T-bill issuance, there is actually a shortage of T-bills out there now relative to capital (complete opposite problem of late-2019 repo spike). 

Short end of the Treasury curve is falling due to collateral shortage, while long end is rising.
Unless Yellen changes plans, then during the next several months, over $1T from the Treasury General Account is going to pour into bank reserves. https://t.co/vHtYyJtyle

Apart from that, large commercial banks have a lot of capacity to absorb Treasuries in 2021 (unlike 2019, when they were tight on capacity). 

They're one of the only places besides the Fed that has the capacity to absorb over $1 trillion in issuance rapidly, if need be.

There's a lot of demand for short duration UST, so the Treasury can keep duration low to reduce the problem. Which they've been doing. 
https://t.co/s5iSIuIQrS

If Treasury runs $3T deficit, and draws down TGA by $1T, that leaves $2T in Treasury security issuance. Fed buys $1T at their current $80B/month rate, leaving $1T for private sector absorb. Doable. 

If Treasury runs $4T deficit, however, that's $2T for private sector. Ouch.

This will require monitoring all year. The problem was going to start earlier, because Treasury was planning a ton of issuance in 1H2021, but under Yellen, the Treasury revised that down on February 1st to draw down TGA for now instead. So now more like a 2H2021 issue. https://t.co/otxmmZz6Cv

If the private sector has to buy it, yields likely go higher, which all else being equal puts pressure on growth equity valuations. 

If the Fed has to step in and buy more Treasuries for lack of sufficient demand, that's kind of Minsky Moment for the dollar.

It'll be interesting to see who has the balance sheet capacity to absorb the Treasury issuance in the second half of 2021, and at what price. 

1H2021 won't have much Treasury issuance, due to the planned TGA drawdown. 2H2021, however, likely gets tight.

@RyanMiller_TE @EmilKalinowski @arjunxkapoor People often think in terms of fiscal or monetary policy alone. 

Fiscal policy re-arranges where the money is; doesn't create it. 

Monetary policy creates money but has no transmission mechanism to the real economy. 

When the two combine, M2 goes up. New money + transmission.

If you're deep into development of Ethereum and bullish on it, then consider my critiques a good thing. Because if you solve various problems, then institutional money may follow. 

On the other hand, I want to make sure folks are aware of risks, to not lose money on altcoins.

Ethereum itself is in rapid development on the base layer, figuring out how to scale, shifting from PoW to PoS, etc. Institutions are hesitant to put billions into a project like that; a small side bet perhaps. 

Hence my 80/20, 90/10, or 100/0 BTC/ETH description in the article.

From there, we'll see what else works in the ecosystem over time if anything. There was an ICO boom/bust, and there is currently a DeFi boom.

Certainly one thing here to stay for a while is stablecoins of various types.

More importantly, I like the BTC project, the ecosystem, what it enables, and the options that it gives to people around the world. 

Permissionless payments and self-custody stores of value are important for the world to have.

For example, when I bought BTC in April 2020 at $6.9k, this ended up being right ahead of a wall of institutional money that came into BTC throughout the year.

The risk/reward ratio was very strong. Not the highest absolute return (could have bought TSLA yolo calls), but great.

I'm not saying I'm dollar bullish this quarter. I'm neutral this quarter; it will depend on what real rates do, who buys the Treasuries, and whether the Fed sticks with their $240 billion quarterly purchase rate or increases it.

For folks asking why, it's because $887 billion in existing dollars has to be extracted from somewhere to buy those other Treasuries. 

If US banks buy the bulk of it, it can remain dollar bearish. If the foreign sector buys the bulk of it, it can be dollar bullish.

With the Treasury set to issue $1,127 billion in net Treasuries  this quarter, and the Fed set to buy $240 billion of them (unless they change), there's a good case for a tactical neutral-to-bullish view on the dollar in Q1 2021, even in a longer-term dollar bearish context.

TLDR; Ethereum could indeed do very well over the next year in terms of price, but as long as it's transforming its base layer, it remains a speculation in alpha development, rather than a finished/stable product.

Debating over what was intended is not generally the ideal path. 

Listening to the market in the long run, through multiple cycles to clear out temporary malinvestment and see what sticks over time, is generally the ideal path.

Among blockchains, the BTC base layer is essentially a finished project (no longer beta) with of course ongoing gradual improvement, while most other blockchains remain experiments in rapid change (alpha/beta versions), with less security and less finality.

And as things develop, the market will dictate who wins in the medium-of-exchange or smart contract race as well. There are Bitcoin layers, there are apps on those networks, there are DeFi projects, other projects, etc. It will be what it will be.

Some folks, however, do have a medium-of-exchange problem as well. People sending small international remittances, and folks that get de-platformed or sanctioned come to mind. 

And for them, there are solutions, including potentially Lightning on BTC over time.

So, the market likes BTC‚Äôs high hash rate settlement network. That‚Äôs where most small money and big money flowed to in the space. 

The market has said rather clearly that it is uninterested in bigger block sizes and trying to expand transaction throughput on the base layer.

Globally, with zero yields everywhere, more people have a ‚Äústore of value‚Äù problem than a ‚Äúmedium of exchange‚Äù problem. 

We have no shortage of quick ways to pay, but we have plenty of difficulty finding things to store wealth in for a long time.

Governments can change market direction to some extent. But countries are in a market competition vs other countries. 

If a country bans something, another country can pick it up and let its people innovate with it, for success or failure.

People can debate about what the market ‚Äúshould‚Äù want, or what Satoshi‚Äôs intent was, but so far, that‚Äôs what hundreds of billions of dollars of capital said it wants. 

And the market gets what it wants, unless or until it wants something else.

Network effects tend to compound, so the winning networks get better hardware, better apps, and more institutional interest, than smaller networks. And that gives them more users, more security, etc.

So, success compounds into more success, unless a major tail risk occurs.

In economics, the market dictates success or failure. 

For years it has spoken, and BCH and BSV have devalued vs BTC in terms of price and hash rate. The market says it likes small blocks, lots of nodes, and Bitcoin as store of value and settlement. https://t.co/acVlPQ4a2R

This is similar to natural selection, with ‚Äúnature‚Äù as the market. Some creatures haven‚Äôt changed in hundreds of millions of years. Others have changed notably, or transformed into something else entirely.

Sometimes the successful product ends up being very different than the engineer initially envisioned. Sometimes it‚Äôs exactly like what they envisioned.

With Bitcoin, there are developer-vs-developer disputes, and disputes between finance-types and earlier users.

This is the type of problem encountered by engineers all the time: trade-offs. 

A project can iterate or stay the same depending on what the market says.

Some folks have applied that to Bitcoin as well. 
https://t.co/NYk1IKFDt4

For example, sometimes there are debates about Satoshi Nakamoto‚Äôs original intent. Should block sizes be increased to facilitate ‚Äúe-cash‚Äù or should block sizes be kept small for any user to run a node?

There‚Äôs an old Zen koan that goes, ‚Äúif you meet the Buddha, kill him.‚Äù 

In other words, when something is self-verifiable or self-iterating, looking too heavily towards the originator can be a distraction along the path. Results speak for themselves.

So, as the Fed-funded stimulus checks go out, bank reserves at the Fed would go up. The Fed ends up with more Treasuries (assets) and more reserves (liabilities) on their balance sheet, just as if they had bought the Treasuries on the secondary market instead.

When banks get that money as new deposits, they hold it as cash until they do something with it (like make loans or buy securities). Other than a trivial amount of vault cash, banks keep all their cash on deposit at the Fed. https://t.co/gAY9gFz0fl

The stimulus checks get deposited by the Treasury into everyone‚Äôs bank account. Their banks then get the cash as an asset, and have new deposit liabilities to their depositors in equal amount. The money is freely spendable by the consumers.

Congress says ‚Äúawesome!‚Äù, and decides to send everyone $5k stimulus checks. They sell the Treasuries directly to the Fed, and the Fed buys them with electronically-printed money. No banks as intermediaries, no secondary market purchases.

Imagine a thought experiment: 

The Federal Reserve Act gets changed, and the Fed is able to print dollars to buy Treasuries directly from the Treasury, rather than on the secondary market.

@gunsandmoney Yes that is their real constraint. 

It's not that they don't make loans due to federal debt being so high; they don't make loans unless they see a good risk/reward opportunity.

Instead what happens with fiscal deficits + QE, is that the whole base rises. Banks end up owning more cash reserves, Treasuries, MBS, and have more loan-making capacity. 

No crowding out effect. https://t.co/dqOYDHo4FW

I see similar analysis in the 2020Q3 Hoisington letter. This appears to be a crux of the inflation-vs-deflation debate. 

However, both private and Fed holdings of UST increased in 2020, because supply increased. Fed buying UST does not necessarily reduce private UST holdings. https://t.co/olaPPGP1cP

@SantiagoAuFund @JamesWMarshall5 Yes but the point is that bank capacity to make loans is not constrained by federal debt levels. 

Federal debt may or may not change bank willingness to make loans, but it doesn't constrain it.
@daflando Japan runs smaller fiscal deficits and grows M2 much more slowly than the US.

More about the mechanics of this here: 
https://t.co/5oinK77YsS

When the government runs large fiscal deficits, and the Fed buys the Treasuries on the secondary market, it sends bank deposits (M2) up a lot, which increases their capital base to buy even more Treasuries or make more loans.

No deflationary "crowding out" effect.

Reflationary.

This article assumes banks are reserve constrained, but they're usually not reserve constrained. 

In 2020, bank holdings of Treasuries, MBS, cash at the Fed, and loans, *all* went up.

Lastly, we can look at the monetary base as a percentage of GDP. When rates hit zero, monetary policy shifts to increasing the monetary base instead (aka QE). https://t.co/ERViwEAsNq

If we separate out federal debt vs nonfederal debt as a percentage of GDP, it also provides more clarity. 

In each long-term cycle, the first stage was a private debt bubble and banking crisis, while the second stage was a public debt bubble and massive M2 increase. https://t.co/yV9K8dh2bB

Another way of looking at it is total debt as a % of M2. 

With this metric, we can see the big changes since 2008 in particular. The ratio dropped from 700% to 400% in 12 years. https://t.co/3ybSph2Xad

When interest rates hit zero for the first time in decades, interesting things happen. 

Here's the 100-year chart of total debt to GDP in blue on the left axis, vs interest rates in orange on the right axis. Total debt includes public and private debt. https://t.co/WQvkDjC2Ey

Bitcoin is not without risk, but like anything else, its potential upside must be compared to the risks that can disrupt it. 

As investors look into it, they can decide for themselves how the fundamentals look, and what role it can serve in their own financial situation.

So, it is in a position today where retail investors and institutional investors can more easily allocate to it, both in terms of investment justification and in terms of tech-accessibility or UX.

That's why I've been bullish since April 2020. So much human capital in Bitcoin.

In the early days, mostly just cypherpunks, visionaries, and speculators bought in. 

But as developers continued to work on it, build better UX, and add additional layers, while also moving slowly and cautiously to avoid catastrophic missteps, it became more tech-accessible.

With each supply cycle and adoption cycle, Bitcoin gets a little bit de-risked. 

Over time, Bitcoin develops more of a price history, grows a stronger surrounding ecosystem of hardware and software, builds more institutional on-ramps, and survives fork wars and altcoin seasons.

Fidelity has been on board for years, and now they have an institutional-grade custody service to absorb institutional allocations. 

Singapore's largest bank is setting up a digital asset exchange for institutional and accredited investors. 
https://t.co/ouEXhvWdFb

There's still plenty of debate, skepticism, and misunderstanding regarding Bitcoin, which is healthy. 

Some institutions are allocating to it, while others move more slowly or avoid it, so there's not a mad-FOMO-rush all at once. There's a wall of worry to climb.

@pecosbill70 To an extent. And US monetary base is one of the fastest increasers vs peers since the repo spike in late 2019. 

Broad money supply matters more though. And the US is increasing its money supply the fastest among developed nations this year.
@mamalicious987 The dollar is down vs a basket of foreign currencies this year. That's what the dollar index is.

"Short dollar" is a bit crowded in a near-term sense (unlike early this year), and a bounce is possible.

But structurally long-term, the fundamental forces still look downward for the USD, unless the Fed substantially tightens, which they have little capacity or incentive to do.

So, when fiscal and monetary policy in the US become loose, the USD historically has plenty of room to fall.

USD demand remains relatively steady year-to-year, while USD supply rapidly shifted from tightening to loosening over the past 16 months.

The US runs persistent current account deficits (weak FX), while Europe and Japan run current account surpluses (strong FX). 

The dollar's strength, therefore, mainly comes from tight monetary policy, along with the global offshore USD debt that represents persistent demand.

This cycle of dollar strength was created by the end of QE in mid-2014, and the initiation of QT in early 2018, all of which made US monetary policy relatively tight vs peers. 

The cycle of strength is seemingly ending, on the cessation of QT into indefinite QE, from late 2019. https://t.co/i44dF9h6wi

@JohnBoyyTrader @LukeGromen @SantiagoAuFund @cartoyzks @LawrenceLepard @johnchew5 @GaricMoran @EPBResearch @coloradotravis The Fed can only lend. Fiscal authorities can spend. When they work together, as they did in the 1940's and again in 2020, they spend from nothing and drive up public deposits and currency in circulation.

@propTrader_ Once they enter bank deposits and/or currency in circulation, they are legal tender. 

That's what makes 2020 different than 2008 in terms of joint fiscal+monetary policy- they did become legal tender this time due to fiscal transmission mechanism.

@EPBResearch GDP, CPI, and velocity would have been far lower without it. $3T not enough to inflate; just enough to counter deflation from debt-laden bust.

In 2008, QE was big, but it just recapitalized banks; there was minimal fiscal transmission to the public.

In 2020, QE was big, and accompanied by multi-trillion fiscal stimulus, so the Fed bought Treasuries, and the Treasury sent folks checks which went into bank deposits & M2.

Here's why QE-alone, and QE+massive fiscal spending, are different. The latter gets into public bank deposits; the former doesn't.

When the zero bound is reached, debts are high, and lending isn't happening, fiscal policy takes over.

Monetary policy still remains relevant for monetizing the high fiscal spending. However, the monetary policy runs low on unilateral tools and takes the supportive role.

People often argue about whether monetary policy or fiscal policy matters more.
