@coloradotravis @EPBResearch @SantiagoAuFund @MichaelArouet @corsola26 @OdzerCapital @MetreSteven Not illegal; I just think some folks misunderstand how reserves work, and specifically the process for which banks can pass through UST+MBS to the Fed at a rate that exceeds bank reserve creation, because the bank reserves are not inert in that sense. https://t.co/HG8ZxG6yOw

@coloradotravis @EPBResearch @SantiagoAuFund @MichaelArouet @corsola26 @OdzerCapital @MetreSteven I suggest any analyst here who thinks reserves are inert, do the following exercise: 

Walk through step by step how banks, with <$100B in vault cash, bought and sold $1.5T in UST to the Fed in Mar/April (without reducing their own UST holdings).

@coloradotravis @EPBResearch @SantiagoAuFund @MichaelArouet @corsola26 @OdzerCapital @MetreSteven Daily purchases were replenished by the Fed; a monthly chart would not show this. Plus, reserves themselves are not lent (neither is the vault cash for that matter).

@coloradotravis @EPBResearch @SantiagoAuFund @MichaelArouet @corsola26 @OdzerCapital @MetreSteven Yes, but that "money" circulates quickly back into the ability to purchase more UST as the Fed buys them. 

Again, banks had <$100B in vault cash, but bought $1.5T in UST and sold to the Fed in Mar/April. The Fed's purchases were not inert, and were recycled to buy more.

@coloradotravis @EPBResearch @SantiagoAuFund @MichaelArouet @corsola26 @OdzerCapital @MetreSteven If reserves were inert, Fed couldn't have bought more UST+MBS than reserves went up. 

Further, the fungibility comes from the fact that no specific reserves are linked to specific assets on a bank's sheet.

@coloradotravis @EPBResearch @SantiagoAuFund @MichaelArouet @corsola26 @OdzerCapital @MetreSteven And the market knows this, which is why inflation breakevens bounced back after their March lows, and reported CPI followed with a bounceback as well. 

The outcome if the Fed had not purchased UST+MBS would have been deflation.

@coloradotravis @EPBResearch @SantiagoAuFund @MichaelArouet @corsola26 @OdzerCapital @MetreSteven Bank reserves increased by less than the amount the Fed purchased; the remainder went into TGA (and a bit into circulation). 

TGA can be drawn down into circulation or back into deposits. 

There is fungibility between bank reserves, TGA, and cash in circulation. 

Inflative.

@coloradotravis @EPBResearch @SantiagoAuFund @MichaelArouet @corsola26 @OdzerCapital @MetreSteven Banks had <$100B in vault cash during March/April, and yet the Fed purchased $1.5T in UST during that time, without decreasing UST holdings by the banks. 

Banks were pass-through entities for this activity; there was no limit to their ability to pass thru to the Fed.

@coloradotravis @EPBResearch @SantiagoAuFund @MichaelArouet @corsola26 @OdzerCapital @MetreSteven It comes from thin air, crediting one account with USD and the other account with UST, as long as the bank meets its capital/reserve reqs.

If Fed wasn't buying, this would obviously be limited. But the bank can re-sell that UST to the Fed and get it off the books.

@coloradotravis @EPBResearch @SantiagoAuFund @MichaelArouet @corsola26 @OdzerCapital @MetreSteven There is no mechanism that links specific portions of reserves to specific assets (loans and securities) on a bank's sheet. 

That is why they are fungible. The bank must simply meet reserve and capital ratios, when lending.

@coloradotravis @EPBResearch @SantiagoAuFund @MichaelArouet @corsola26 @OdzerCapital @MetreSteven Primary dealers buy UST at auction. 

But that's not even the key issue. Banks can technically buy UST+MBS from anywhere and sell to the Fed, repeatedly citing the same reserve pool, with no limit other than the amount that the Fed is willing to buy at that time.

@coloradotravis @EPBResearch @SantiagoAuFund @MichaelArouet @corsola26 @OdzerCapital @MetreSteven Reserves are not used for debt origination. They are merely referenced for debt origination. 

Banks don't lend reserves. They just have to *have* the reserves to lend, to meet capital requirements. Important difference.

@coloradotravis @EPBResearch @SantiagoAuFund @MichaelArouet @corsola26 @OdzerCapital @MetreSteven They credit the government with cash. The government credits the bank with UST. Lending creates deposits.

USTs no longer even count against capital requirements as of like March, but if they still did, the bank merely points to their reserves, rather than drawing from them.

@coloradotravis @EPBResearch @SantiagoAuFund @MichaelArouet @corsola26 @OdzerCapital @MetreSteven Which is why the same pool of reserves can be cited, repeatedly, for whatever loan the bank makes or whatever security they buy, and they can re-sell them to the Fed and get them off their own books again, and then repeat.

@coloradotravis @EPBResearch @SantiagoAuFund @MichaelArouet @corsola26 @OdzerCapital @MetreSteven Exactly, they don't use the reserves. 

They merely have to *have* the reserves, in order to lend. They don't actually transfer anything out of reserves to make the purchase; they just have to cite the existence of those reserves to avoid violating leverage ratios and such.

@coloradotravis @EPBResearch @SantiagoAuFund @MichaelArouet @corsola26 @OdzerCapital @MetreSteven Banks don't lend from reserves; they just have reserves to maintain capital ratios. There is no way to link specific reserves to specific loans/securities on a bank's balance sheet, including UST. 

Thus, banks can buy and re-sell UST to Fed ad infinitum using the same reserves.

@coloradotravis @EPBResearch @SantiagoAuFund @MichaelArouet @corsola26 @OdzerCapital @MetreSteven Except they are not inert. If they were inert, then Fed UST+MBS holdings would be constrained by those reserve numbers, but they aren't. 

They are fungible because banks don't even lend reserves, in terms of the mechanics. They just have reserves to maintain capital ratios.

@coloradotravis @EPBResearch @SantiagoAuFund @MichaelArouet @corsola26 @OdzerCapital @MetreSteven They immediately can be re-lent for more USTs to pass through to the Fed. Otherwise, Fed UST+MBS would be constrained by the sum of bank reserves. 

And more specifically, banks don't even lend reserves; they just have reserves to maintain capital ratios.

@EPBResearch @coloradotravis @SantiagoAuFund @MichaelArouet @corsola26 @OdzerCapital @MetreSteven How are you defining bank cash here? 

For all intents and purposes, bank cash and deposits with the Fed are the same number. The difference between the two is the tiny amount of vault cash. https://t.co/bAzCGbbIqI

@coloradotravis @EPBResearch @SantiagoAuFund @MichaelArouet @corsola26 @OdzerCapital @MetreSteven It was not extracted from anywhere. It was created ex nihilo. 

When Federal debt increases and real buyers buy it with existing USD, it is extractive. When debt increases and winds up on Fed balance sheet from new money creation, it was not extractive. Paid for with new USD.

@EPBResearch @coloradotravis @SantiagoAuFund @MichaelArouet @corsola26 @OdzerCapital @MetreSteven From the Fed's previous purchases of UST/MBS from the PDs in the prior round, essentially. 

They don't lend from reserves, but they have reserves to maintain capital ratios.

@SantiagoAuFund @EPBResearch @coloradotravis @MichaelArouet @corsola26 @OdzerCapital @MetreSteven Yes they can be, because they are fungible. If not, then Fed wouldn't be able to buy $5.5T in UST+MBS while bank reserves go up $2.7T.

@coloradotravis @EPBResearch @SantiagoAuFund @MichaelArouet @corsola26 @OdzerCapital @MetreSteven It is monetization, because there is no limit, and doesn't get unwound (other than brief and feeble attempts like QT).

@coloradotravis @EPBResearch @SantiagoAuFund @MichaelArouet @corsola26 @OdzerCapital @MetreSteven And because they are fungible, for example: 

Treasury could decide to give everyone $20K, issue tens of trillions of UST to do so, PD banks buy it and immediately sell to Fed through new USD creation, all of that winds up on Fed bs, and that cash gets to real economy.

There was a four-decade period of negative real yields where it made little sense to hold Treasuries or cash; that is when most dollar devaluation occurred.

Unsurprisingly, the time period where it was illegal to hold gold happens to align almost perfectly with that period. https://t.co/AekkNvsHH1

When policymakers favor this perspective, an individual response from a game theory perspective is to shift out of the dollar system (Treasuries and bank accts with negative real yields) where possible until they pay real yields again.

Hence, gold recently hit $2k.

In other words, when Treasuries and bank accounts pay you a solid yield above inflation, that tends to be a good environment for savers.

When Treasuries and bank accounts don't keep up with inflation, historically it's better to shift to scarce assets to preserve buying power.

For folks mentioning that you can take dollars and invest them to get more dollars (to offset the devaluation), keep in mind that the bulk of currency devaluation occurred during long periods of negative real yields, like the 1940's and 1970's (and what we are looking like now). https://t.co/lODjxedpZA

On the other hand, the U.S. did the least QE as a percentage of GDP, and yet has the highest wealth inequality among major developed nations.

China and Europe performed middling amounts of QE as a percentage of GDP, and have middling wealth inequality. https://t.co/xU3Mj9FJfl

Japan did the most QE in terms of how long they did it, and what percentage of GDP they did it. And yet, they have among the lowest inequality, and the share of assets among the top 1% actually deceased over the span of doing it. https://t.co/ZqFaumH9xh

It's a common view that QE leads to wealth inequality, and this view is largely justified. 

Here's a weird fact though: Between Japan, Europe, China, and the United States, there is an *inverse* correlation between the amount of QE they did as a % of GDP, and wealth inequality.

So we have a situation where the Fed accumulated more Treasuries within six weeks in early 2020, than the entire foreign sector accumulated over the past six years. 

It's debt monetization, with primary dealers as the intermediaries. https://t.co/ZLTMGrw1hy

This is common in strong dollar environments. When the dollar becomes strong (blue line), the foreign sector share of Treasury ownership decreases (green line), historically speaking. https://t.co/9NS3Sq7W39

Foreigners hold the smallest share of US debt since 2002. 

People can point to small individual bond auctions all they want, and periods of foreign demand, but structurally, foreigners simply aren't buying Treasuries as quickly as the U.S. government is issuing them.

The gold-to-S&P 500 ratio recently broke above its 50-month moving average in 2019/2020. It previously broke above that trend line in 2001, and fell below it in 2012.

It's one of the simpler long-term momentum comparisons between gold and stocks, and it currently favors gold. https://t.co/BNe0PfOWIY

Gold's price in year-over-year terms tends to inversely correlate with the inflation-adjusted 10-year yield. 

When real rates are positive, the opportunity cost for owning gold is high. When real rates are low/negative, it makes more sense to have gold exposure. https://t.co/ab0Jm50R2o

Over the past ~50 years, gold's price rose at about the same rate as monetary inflation per capita (which is not the same as price inflation). 

It tended to overshoot that trend during periods of low real rates, and undershoot that trend during periods of high real rates.

This chart shows the price of gold vs broad money supply per capita, normalized to 100 in 1973, on the left axis. 

On the right axis, is the inflation-adjusted interest rate of the U.S. 10-year Treasury note. https://t.co/zvfOb2HKgA

@sherwoodseo It's a lot more expensive and time consuming to prototype mechanical systems. Slower iteration. 

Movement, energy, and material properties have stricter limits via physics. What works on paper often is clunky in practice, hard to make economical.

@SAE_Thoughts Actual technology, not stocks. 

In other words, airplanes today are not really that much better than 25 years ago, but electronics and software are outrageously better.

Some technologies are inherently more exponential, especially if they are virtualized and thus fast-iterating. 

Technology that interacts with the physical world in more direct ways, such as mechanical systems (including aerospace) tends to be much, much slower to iterate.

Decades ago, folks thought we'd have flying cars and way more space travel by now. And physical robotics is very, very hard, including self-driving cars, etc. 

However, smart phones, apps, cloud computing, all sorts of electronics and software, moved past what many expected.

Historically, it seems that people tend to: 

1) Underestimate the future growth rate of electronic + software technology. 

2) Overestimate the future growth rate of mechanical + aerospace technology.

@hurshidn Foreigners sold $300B Treasuries in March and April. 

Wasn't just Treasuries though. All assets become fair game if USD spikes, which is why the Fed stepped in. The Treasury market causes the most damage if it breaks.

@AlexClouse It matters because in addition to canceling each other out on net, foreign countries also own $40T in US assets on top of that, and can sell those to get USD if needed. 

That is the mechanism that stunts dollar spikes by forcing the Fed to self-correct and provide USD liquidity.
@agjohnst Because individual institutions can have solvency problems but major countries themselves are not dollar insolvent, as the "global dollar shortage" often presents the argument.

@SantiagoAuFund @grasbueschel @amlivemon @kimgits1 @CF_Poet Because that mechanism of the foreign sector using their US assets as forced collateral to sell is precisely what limits the magnitude/and or duration of potential USD spikes. 

And they didn't have that mechanism in the 1980s USD superspike. They owned far fewer US assets.

@grasbueschel @amlivemon @kimgits1 @SantiagoAuFund @CF_Poet We can include nominal derivative levels (much of which are very short term, and again much of which net out), but I think the debt held by non-financial corps and govts is the most relevant figure, especially when looking at a country by country basis.

@grasbueschel @amlivemon @kimgits1 @SantiagoAuFund @CF_Poet The dollar short/neutral position actually has nothing to do with size, because regardless of size, it is not primarily owed to the US. It is owed among nations and institutions. So size is a question of how leveraged, not how short, when discussing the ex-USA world as a whole.

This is why, although there can be more USD tightness or perhaps even another brief spike, I consider a strong probability of being near the end of this current dollar bull cycle, ever since the Fed was forced to shift to QE in Sep 2019. https://t.co/6YVy340hn9

The US went into this pandemic with the biggest fiscal deficit as a % of GDP among major developed countries, and have been the biggest spender/printer as a % of GDP in this pandemic as well. The US also has a structural trade deficit. https://t.co/EVNLOMMldM

The median American has less wealth than the median Japanese or European citizen. The US has more wealth concentration, more reliance on the service sector, more people on the brink of insolvency. 

Probably tons of fiscal coming over the next 3-5 years. https://t.co/9hTAFdgGkY

Since September 2019 (repo spike) and especially since March 2020, the Fed has grown its balance sheet faster than ECB or BOJ in absolute terms and as a percentage of GDP. 

Others might play catch-up in 2H2020, but US is also likely to do more fiscal then as well. https://t.co/tjUDSk9ZUs

This is why the dollar tends to trade in big cycles. Periods of extreme tightness end up negatively affecting the US (asset prices, corporate profits), and forcing the Fed to shift to more dovish policy, which eventually relieves the dollar. 

In other words, this chart again: https://t.co/V140l1qOUq

Here is the Fed describing the US Treasury market ceasing to function effectively in March, resulting in the Fed doing up to $75B/day in peak QE, extending swap lines, and launching an alphabet soup of programs. https://t.co/ljjK0hFDvH

But as described, a strong dollar also creates a liquidity issue for the US, especially during an acute USD spike causing stronger foreign markets to sell some of their US assets to get USD. So, the US really doesn‚Äôt have much leverage against other big countries.

For weak EM and a large portion of frontier markets, a strong dollar is a solvency issue for them (not just liquidity), because they have USD debts but not really much USD assets. 

Many of them are still in danger. Most of them don't have swap lines anyway. Localized problems.

For big economic areas (Europe, Japan, China, and some major EM), a strong dollar is a liquidity issue, not a solvency issue. They have more USD assets than liabilities. Europe and Japan in particular together have $115T in net worth, including a lot of USD assets.

So, the idea that we should avoid investing in jurisdictions without swap lines, or that the US will pressure a variety of individual countries with swap line threats, doesn‚Äôt add up. Swap lines mainly went to places that are not USD insolvent, but USD illiquid (ECB + BOJ).

Some people think the US will weaponize swap lines among those 15+ foreign CBs. However, almost all of the swap line funding went to ECB, BOJ, and BOE. Most other countries barely used the swap lines. https://t.co/Xeah4g8a6g

The Fed provided USD liquidity swaps (blue line below) with at least 15 foreign central banks to relieve global USD shortage and stop forced-selling of US assets (red line). So far, that worked, with the TED spread down, and foreign sector no longer selling Treasuries. https://t.co/mDhVMdF4Tv

In fact, the Fed accumulated more US Treasuries in March and April by printing new dollars, than the entire foreign sector accumulated in the past 6-7 years. 

In other words, debt monetization quickly outpaced foreign lending. https://t.co/ePcmVbsUqb

In March and April, the foreign sector sold $300B in US Treasuries at a time when the Treasury was about to do record Treasury issuance, and the Treasury market became illiquid. The Fed cited this repeatedly, and started buying Treasuries and lending USD swap lines.
This chart shows total US federal debt (red), the foreign-held portion of those Treasuries (blue), and the percentage of US debt held by foreigners (green). https://t.co/s3oiGDnnrX

This chart shows the % of US Treasuries held by foreigners compared to the trade-weighted dollar. When USD gets strong, foreigners don‚Äôt really buy much Treasuries, even though Treasury supply keeps increasing due to fiscal deficits. Foreign % of US funding diminishes. https://t.co/77v1zbvmsm

During the three major USD bull cycles since 1971, when the USD gets very strong, foreigners buy fewer Treasuries, forcing the US domestic sector (‚Äúcrowding out‚Äù effect) or the Fed (‚Äúdebt monetization‚Äù) to buy most new Treasury supply.
Sharp dollar spikes tend to coincide with sharp US market sell-offs. https://t.co/qNsplKk0FK

When trade diminishes and it becomes harder for the foreign sector to get dollars, it can cause a squeeze in the dollar to high levels. This is bad for liquidity, and can force some countries to sell U.S. assets to get dollars.

In addition to that rather balanced USD position overall (on both asset & liab sides of the $12T USD debt), the collective ex-US world owns $40T in gross US assets (treasuries, stocks, real estate, corp bonds) on top of that, built from decades of accumulated U.S. trade deficits. https://t.co/szGuKga0xu

In other words, the collective ex-US world is not ‚Äúshort USD‚Äù. They are collectively ‚Äúleveraged USD‚Äù, having both long and short USD positions among themselves. That is a key distinction. 

There are individual places that are very net short USD (ie Chile, Argentina‚Ä¶). https://t.co/DqOkOeCaUQ

However, most of that $12T offshore USD debt is not owed to US institutions.

It is mostly owed to other non-US institutions. (ie Chinese or European firms lend to other countries in USD), so it mostly nets out for assets and liabilities. (Someone‚Äôs liab is someone else‚Äôs asset.) https://t.co/gcRoukPh5V

Many people are rightly concerned about offshore USD debt, because govts and corporations that have USD-denominated debt but exist outside of the US have less access to the Fed as a funding backstop. 

About $8T of that $12T is in advanced nations, and $4T is in EM.

However, governments and nonfinancial corporations outside of the U.S. also hold $12+ trillion in USD-denominated debt, since it‚Äôs the most-used global currency. 

And they rely on USD-based global trade to get dollars to service those debts. https://t.co/FCF89ivkvu

Here‚Äôs a new thread on the dollar, swap lines, and the treasury market. With lots of charts.üßê

AKA ‚ÄúWhy the global dollar shortage is not insurmountable.‚Äù https://t.co/k1G9cfaAvj

@RenoHemonc Yes, they devalued from 1/20th to 1/35th an oz of gold per dollar. (Still had fractional reserve banking then.)

Then in the 1940s they had significant inflation despite being gold-backed as money-printing ramped up.

Wouldn't be surprised to see an echo in this generation. 

2010's: private debt as a % of GDP peaks, bank crisis, major QE, but dis-inflationary recapitalization environment

2020's: federal debt as a % of GDP peaks, major crisis spending, eventually CPI inflationary

In the early 1930's, private debt as a % of GDP peaked, bank crisis, and dollars were devalued vs gold, but without much CPI inflation. 

Then in the more inflationary 1940's war era, federal debt as a % of GDP peaked, and currency was devalued again, this time CPI inflationary.

@jackmsuckling1 @cullenroche @pnw_mikeyb @KaMiller1 Yes, the current variety of QE gets more to the public and thus has an eventual ability to increase consumer price inflation (after the current deflationary shock) whereas the type from 2008 was mostly about bank recapitalization and boosting asset prices.

@jackmsuckling1 @cullenroche @pnw_mikeyb @KaMiller1 Most of their QE was just debt monetization. It offset huge deflationary forces but not enough to cause high inflation.

They did increase asset prices of both stocks and bonds, particularly when they ramped up the BOJ balance sheet from 30% to 100% of GDP.

@cullenroche @pnw_mikeyb @KaMiller1 As for whether it affects lending, it's important to keep in mind that primary dealers have to buy Treasuries at auction. Whether they can re-sell them or not is another matter, and will constrain lending if they can't.

Fed fixes that buy doing QE to take those Treasuries.

@cullenroche @pnw_mikeyb @KaMiller1 (I've posted in about 2 of your threads ever, when they've popped up on feeds.)

For the papers, consider that this particular discussion began when you said QE doesn't affect stock prices. One of your cited papers claims otherwise. https://t.co/DYEABWW69p

@dandolfa @cullenroche Yes, banks in Sep 2019 had their lowest post-GFC (and thus post newer regulations) cash levels as a % of assets, and highest Treasury security % of assets. Constrained liquidity.

So, Fed began buying T-bills from the banks. https://t.co/03BxDBt6TO

@Solomon_Slate @cullenroche @KaMiller1 During the week of the repo spike in Sep 2019, cash as a % of assets at large US banks reached post-GFC lows while Treasury holdings as a % of assets reached record highs. 

Fed addressed it first by lending in repo, and then by T-bill QE to keep cash from going lower. https://t.co/ObrWA3EALb

@cullenroche @dandolfa @KaMiller1 Yes, at the margins. But the banking industry as a whole can't re-liquify by unloading trillions of Treasuries and MBS to households. 

Households aren't buying them at scale. Even if they tried, think about where the cash would come from to do so: from bank deposits...?

@cullenroche @KaMiller1 Not in a liquidity crisis, and not when the banking industry as a whole is filled with record securities as % of assets (as they were in Sep 2019) with low cash levels. Wouldn't be enough buyers. 

So Fed buys them and refills bank reserve levels as an industry. More liquidity.

@cullenroche @dandolfa @KaMiller1 One bank can sell securities if they want to make loans.

When all large banks are filled to the brim securities, the industry as a whole can't sell. The Fed comes in at scale, creates reserves ex nihilo, buys aome securities, re-liquifies the banks, and now they can buy more.

@cullenroche @KaMiller1 To get to the heart of the matter.

After QE3 filled big banks to 15% cash by 2014 (and 15% agency/Treasury securities), they spent the next 5 yrs accumulating securities and went to 7% cash and 22% securities, ran into liquidity limits, and repo spike. Fed then bought some (QE).

@cullenroche @dandolfa @KaMiller1 It does if they are at actually liquidity constrained due to having filled up with securities, like in Sep 2019 when large banks had collectively fallen to levels of cash at just 7% of assets.

So, Fed created reserves, bought securities from banks, and re-liquified them.

@cullenroche @KaMiller1 And that new composition is liquid and lets them lend more.

A hypothetical bank filled up to reserve limits with MBS, for example, can't lend more. Fed creates reserves ex nihilo, swaps it for some of the bank's MBS, and the bank now has a high reserve ratio and can lend more.

@dandolfa @KaMiller1 @cullenroche Yes, especially if done to many banks rather than one. One bank can sell assets to get liquidity, but all banks together can't do that unless Fed creates reserves ex nihilo and swaps them for those assets at scale. Fed moves assets onto its sheet and banks can lend again.

@KaMiller1 @cullenroche @dandolfa I didn't mention credit quality. Suppose in the example that the $10B in loans that the Fed buys from the bank are safe MBS. It frees capital up to lend more. 

Now recently with the SPV, the Fed can indirectly buy some worse credit stuff as well, but that's a separate point.

@KaMiller1 @cullenroche Rough example: Bank has $100B loans (assets) and $95B deposits (liabs). $5B cash equity. Bank can't really lend more. 

Fed creates $10B cash ex nihilo & buys $10B in loans from bank. Bank now has $90B loans, $95B deposits, and $15B cash equity. Bank can lend more now.

@cullenroche Yes, so ask what happens when their capital is leveraged up to regulatory limits. Can't lend more.

But, CB can create currency ex nihilo, swap that currency for some of those loans (like MBS), which frees up capital for that bank to lend more.

@cullenroche Banks in the real world have regulatory limits on how much reserves they need as a % of assets for solvency.

A tiny bank with tiny equity can't make a $50 billion loan, for example, even though "lending creates deposits". They  wouldnt have the deposits/equity to do so.

@ManuelPolavieja @cullenroche @hasufl Only for Treasuries because the Fed cited some liquidity/demand issues in the Treasury market and wanted banks to be able to keep buying them (they had previously not had enough cash to buy more without running into some regulatory issues).

@ManuelPolavieja @hasufl @cullenroche Yes they do lend more, but it is often to the government by buying Treasury securities, like from 2014-2019.

In that sense, QE monetizes some of the deficit spending and is a framework for a government to inject more capital into an economy than they extract from it.

@ManuelPolavieja @hasufl @cullenroche The net add doesn't end up in the banks. It ends up elsewhere in the system through the banks. 

With QE, the CB creates currency, and swaps that currency for existing loans/assets at banks, which fills the banks with liquid cash, which allows them to lend more.
@n4hpg They create it.

@ManuelPolavieja @hasufl @cullenroche When performing QE, the central bank creates new digital currency, and then swaps that new currency for existing assets from banks, meaning that a net amount of liquidity was added to the financial system.

The swap itself is neutral, but the currency for the swap is a net add.

We saw a similar TED and liquidity swap action back in 2012 but on a smaller scale. https://t.co/ibAiS0Zc2v

@cullenroche @cfischer6 More broadly, whenever a country's government debts gets over like 90% (Japan, Eurozone, USA), the amount of supply on the market is so high that the central bank becomes the primary buyer of it, for lack of enough private balance sheet space.

@cullenroche @cfischer6 When supply is excessive relative to available buyers, yes. 

A deflationary environment leads to lower UST yields UNLESS foreigners simply can't buy any more and need to sell to get dollars. In which case, the Fed becomes the primary UST buyer, as they have been since Sep 2019.

@cullenroche @cfischer6 It's been an aggregate Treasury demand problem for a few years, which ran into a head in September 2019 when the Fed became the primary buyer. The mid-March liquidity event was a microcosm of what happens on a larger/longer scale.

https://t.co/2HxPJ6ekTZ

@cullenroche @cfischer6 At the current time, we've been in an environment of low foreign Treasury demand, and modest domestic demand, and high supply, so the Fed has taken over as the primary buyer of Treasuries since September 2019. 

This is separate from the deflation trade, and overrides it.

@cullenroche @cfischer6 What we saw in mid-March was a liquidity-driven microcosm of that larger causal relationship. 

In strong dollar environments (especially an acute shortage like in mid-March), foreigners need dollars, not Treasuries. They can sell Treasuries to get dollars.

@cullenroche @cfischer6 What this means is that in strong dollar environments, foreigners need dollars rather than Treasuries, and a greater share of the federal debt needs to be bought by domestic sources, or if those domestic sources aren't buying, then the Federal Reserve via debt monetization.

@cullenroche @LeverageDrag @cfischer6 That's a lot of speculation. 

If there is plenty of demand for UST, particularly the long end, why not just let the market settle on its own? Why buy $1.4 trillion in Treasuries in six weeks, after citing a wide/bid ask spread and problematic selling during a yield spike?

@cullenroche @cfischer6 Rather than cherry picking, I'm going down to deeper resolution to see what actually happened week-by-week and why, rather than drawing a 4-month line and saying, "yields went down".

Deflation trade, foreign selling, Fed buying, were all dominate variables in specific weeks.

@cullenroche @cfischer6 We have the actual data though, and that's not what happened. Yields initially fell (as per deflation expectation), but then upon foreign selling, suddenly shot back up with very wide bid/ask, and Fed cited this as a problem and began aggressively buying. Then yields back down.

@LeverageDrag @cullenroche @cfischer6 Yep and that spike in Treasury bid/ask was cited by the Fed as a problem multiple times, so they ramped up purchases to make the market liquid again on the buyer side. 

Not sure why people are talking about "Fed conspiracy theories". Just discussing what Fed cited and did.

@cullenroche @cfischer6 Not cherry picking. Yields fell on their own first. But then when dollar liquidity shortage occurred, foreigners sold Treasuries, sharply and yields spiked back up.

Fed cited this dYsfunction, and bought Treasuries aggressively, then did swaps and other liquidity operations.

@cullenroche @cfischer6 Rates on the long end, yes. And that's what happened after initial decline, until Fed started buying aggressively (specific Mar 9 to Mar 18)

@cullenroche @cfischer6 Look at Mar 9 to Mar 18 when yields doubled (rather than draw a 4-month line), and the timing of the Fed ramping up their Treasury purchases (during that spike), combined with their FOMC meeting minutes citing lack of liquidity and problematic Treasury selling.

@cullenroche @cfischer6 After initial decline, yields more than doubled from Mar 9 to Mar 18. And UST market became illiquid.

That's the spike I'm talking about. And that's when the Fed ramped up Treasury purchases from $4B/day to $37B/day and then to $75B/day. Helped push yields back down. https://t.co/wfBPkz6Rp9

@cullenroche @cfischer6 Look at order of events. 

Yields fell, but then spiked back. During that spike, wide bid/ask.

Second, they provided swaps/intl repo later to avoid further foreign sales by providing USD liquidity. https://t.co/c9JIGRr1cI

@cullenroche @cfischer6 It's not a Fed conspiracy; they outright say it in meeting minutes and press releases. 

Low rates are for a variety of reasons, but the long end of the Treasury market crashed (yields up, wide bid/ask), so Fed ramped up purchases of Treasuries and provided swap liquidity.

@cullenroche @cfischer6 Yes, because the Fed started buying $75B/day by then. 

Later, foreigners stopped selling when other avenues of dollar liquidity (swaps, intl repo) were made available to them.

@cfischer6 @cullenroche Exactly. The Fed is very transparent about it. They said in press releases and in meeting minutes that disfunction in the Treasury market led to some of their policies of buying Treasuries, letting foreigners lend Treasuries for dollar collateral to avoid market sales, etc.

@cullenroche @cfischer6 And we have the data, so it's not speculation. Foreigners sold Treasuries in early March. They stopped selling (as of latest data), once the Fed initiated swap lines, international repo, and tamed down the dollar spike. https://t.co/Setx35Heqj

If my blog existed in the early 2000's, I probably would have gotten a lot of emails about emerging markets and "BRIC" investing. 

Takeaway: If you're excited about something, or a lot of people are excited about something, be careful and manage risk appropriately.

My reader emails have been a strong contrarian indicator; lots of retail readers from Google. So far, no big email theme in 2020, but it's been a fear-based market anyway.

FinTwit is a bit more niche, so plenty of people still interested in gold and BTC. I don't see much pot.

After pot stocks crashed, in 2019 I got a ton of emails about gold stocks; people excited about them. 

Unlike pot and BTC, I do invest in precious metals and like them. However, I warned a couple times about excited sentiment; focusing on the long run and remaining diversified.

After bitcoin crashed from its late 2017 peak, in 2018 I got a ton of emails about pot stocks; people excited about them. 

I didn't invest in any pot stocks and my email responses to readers warned about overvaluation and to be cautious in the space.

I wrote my BTC article back in 2017 because, due to the surging price, I got a ton of emails from people about it and excited with it.

So I wrote my article to chill people out and provide a sober analysis of pros and cons. The neutral outlook ended up being good for 2-3 years.

Now in 2020, I lean a bit more bullish on BTC. I still prefer gold/silver/miners overall, but BTC is a play on the same theme of debasement of global fiat and excessive liquidity coming in the years ahead. Big upside and downside potential.

BTC halving is another nice catalyst.

A lot of people ask me about bitcoin.

I wrote one article on bitcoin back in 2017 with a neutral outlook, and the bitcoin price has been volatile but largely sideways since then, and is now at a price roughly the same as when the article was written.

https://t.co/HlQP7lC4ET

When analyzing who has the upper hand and how this likely plays out, consider that the U.S. is helping its creditors not do disorderly fire-sales of its assets. 

The U.S. is the net debtor rather than the net creditor in this scenario. It's our stuff that they would sell.

For example, Korea is using a $12 billion swap to help out its banks. However, they also have $121 billion in U.S. treasuries. The swap line is there by the U.S. to avoid Korea having to sell U.S. treasuries. 
https://t.co/GG36xpLFIY

Some nations are in better shape than others, because their FX reserves (stored in dollars and other convertible currencies like euros or gold) exceed their dollar-denominated liabilities. Others are not so lucky. 

Here are the major EMs FX reserves and USD debts as % of GDP: https://t.co/x62nYDHcRj

All of these dollar swap lines that the Fed is doing with nations is not out of the kindness of their heart. It's to avoid the prospect of foreigners selling $39 trillion in U.S. assets, including especially $7 trillion in U.S. treasuries, by biding time.

This forced-selling applies to government bonds, corporate bonds, real estate, and stocks. 

People often ask how dollars can get out of U.S. besides trade. Selling U.S. assets is how. Some of the $39 trillion that foreigners own gross, starting with about $7 trillion in UST.

So, when foreigners are short dollars, they can sell their U.S. assets to get dollars. As a specific example, foreigners liquidate their Treasury holdings that they hold at the Fed (custodian) in response to dollar spikes: https://t.co/z3KF7ep3zY

The U.S. used to be the world's largest creditor nation. Now we are the world's largest debtor nation. Our net international investment position continues to deteriorate as a % of GDP: https://t.co/cTtLD3oqbN
The other side of the ledger is often ignored by the dollar bull camp. Foreigners own $39 trillion of U.S. assets. (The U.S. only owns $28 trillion of foreign assets.) https://t.co/l7R8GCjCCP

The dollar bull vs dollar bear debate often focuses on the $12 trillion or more in dollar-denominated debt that exists outside of the United States. 

However... (thread) https://t.co/rLCLlDEOhu

@shahabp777 Group A has half of consumer debt and a third of total liabities. Considering how bank leverage operates, and how small of a contraction it takes to cause a recession, it seems pretty vulnerable. 

It does self correct in part, but usually unpleasantly during recessions.

When estimating the health of the consumer, it's helpful to separate the overall picture into smaller groups, because those groups are radically different, and this fact is masked by the broad average.

https://t.co/YRpaC2dBXC

Therefore, the argument that "high debt levels are okay because the nation's average debt servicing costs vs income are low" is basically saying, "it's okay that Group A has plenty of consumer debt, because this different Group B has plenty of income."

More broadly, 90% of consumer debt is held by the bottom 90% wealth groups, who earn about half of the nation's income and have just a third of the nation's assets. 

The top 10% have about half the income, two thirds of the assets, and still just 10% of consumer debt.

However, keep in mind that over half of consumer debt is held by the bottom 50% of the population, who collectively earn only 12% of the nation's annual income and have just 6% of the nation's total assets. https://t.co/STkMxWiCU2
People sometimes point out that debt servicing costs are low as a percentage of income, so high consumer credit or high total household debt is okay. https://t.co/vK5G24D99I
As consumer credit as a percent of GDP hangs out at record levels, it's worth keeping in mind the problem of averages. https://t.co/R97tqTXfDE

Of course, as weeks and months go by in Q1, continue to evaluate deficit funding situation, including foreign holding of treasuries (they likely peaked in August 2019 based on current data), repo levels, Fed T-bill buying rates, etc, in order to refine over time.

At current rates, even if repo winds down to zero (not my base case, but let's suppose), the Fed's outright t-bill purchase program will lead to new balance sheet highs in about 2 months. 

So, base case is relative $DXY strength through much of Q1, then potential weakness.

The Fed's outright t-bill purchases have reduced the need for repo operations, since these are all various methods, direct or indirect, for funding U.S. deficits. (In other words, they can buy t-bills, or lend money to institutions to buy t-bills.)

@JasonEBurack Good video. 

IMO it is 3 key variables in the tug of war rather than 2. Until September, it was 2vs1 in favor of a stronger dollar. Then in September, one variable changed sides; now 1vs2 in favor of a weaker dollar. 

See thread: 
https://t.co/MXOpGooWdK

For reasons described in the thread above, these variables will likely be 1vs2 for quite a while, after many years of being 2vs1. 

There may be corrections against the trend, but the overall trend is likely bearish for the dollar until the variables get re-arranged again.

Until the September repo spike, these variables were 2vs1 in favor of a stronger dollar. The global dollar shortage and tight U.S. monetary policy were bullish for the dollar, while the bearish balance of payments variable sat in the background, pushed aside for a time.

The third variable is U.S. monetary policy; interest rates and central bank liquidity actions. 

For five years from 2014-2019, the U.S. had the tightest policy among developed nations. 

This flipped like a switch in September; now the Fed is aggressively printing. https://t.co/fGujI6CXJU

The second variable is the global dollar liquidity shortage. Offshore entities, especially in EM, borrowed a lot of dollars as the reserve currency with lower rates, and have a high demand for dollars to service that debt. That's a bullish dollar variable.

One variable is the U.S. balance of payments and net international investment position; which are deeply negative. This is the most decisive but slow-acting variable, is often overlooked, and is a long-term dollar bear variable. 

More here: 
https://t.co/jtvYkQylqk

It is helpful to think of the #dollar direction has having three key variables at the moment. 

A bit pivot occurred in September, and it is still being interpreted in various ways. A short thread. https://t.co/1ELhsSfVXV

@TradingTrotter As primary dealers, it's their job to make sure UST auctions go well, to make a liquid market for them.

A lot of people think the Fed is trying to support the equity market, or covering for a bank/fund failure somewhere. Those explanations are possible, but not required. The Fed simply taking over as the primary financier of U.S. deficits is a mathematically sufficient reason.

Zooming in on that last chart, large bank cash levels hit lows of just 7.25% of assets the same week of the repo spike and Fed intervention in the repo market. They rebounded back up to 8.26% since the Fed became the relief buyer of treasuries and banks were off the hook. https://t.co/zmMu04qzDW

For years, large U.S. banks were drawing down cash levels (15% to 7% of assets in last 5yr) to buy treasuries (from 15% to 21% of assets). But now they are basically at regulatory limits; can't draw down cash to buy more treasuries. So, the Fed became the new buyer of them. https://t.co/27JQjdTwx9

Last week alone, the Fed bought another $28 billion in treasuries while continuing to sell mortgage-backed securities on net. Because it's mainly about deficit-funding, not just liquidity. Excess UST supply + dollar shortage = they will create dollars to buy UST for a long time. https://t.co/ytmuEP0g1g

Thread about impacts of potential legislation to block U.S. federal/military pension system from investing in a broad MSCI index that would include certain countries:
https://t.co/y0WINJ6eT3

This is a case where financial professionals concluded that broadening the number of countries in a standard index similar to Vanguard/Fidelity may improve risk-adjusted returns, but politicians may choose to block individual countries, complicating matters.
Investors should be aware of numbers and context when contemplating the geopolitical macro implications of something like this, and whether it impacts their investment process.

Right or wrong, this symbolic gesture may perhaps impact goodwill, but it has no serious numerical impact on China. Being limited to the MSCI EAFE index as their only international exposure with no EM may, however, meaningfully impact federal/military personnel TSP returns.

For example, $5 billion is about 0.07% the size of China's stock market capitalization, or less than 0.5% of the amount of U.S. treasuries that China holds, or less than 0.04% of China's GDP. Keeping scale in mind is important.

However, the I Fund has $50 billion in AUM, and this new index would put approx 10% into China, or about $5 billion. For comparison, China‚Äôs equity market cap is in the ballpark of $7 trillion. China holds over $1 trillion in U.S. sovereign debt. $5 billion is insignificant.

Some of these folks, as well as some investors, think that this could have big global macro implications such as hurting China‚Äôs capital account or affecting their dollar needs. Plus, it sounds fair to some, like blocking access to countries with different values or accounting.

By the end of 2017, the TSP board decided to switch the I Fund to the broader MSCI ACWI Ex-USA IMI, which invests in 99% of the ex-USA equity market cap. It has about a quarter of its funds in EM, just based on the passive cap-weighted system. Not very controversial.

It‚Äôs probably a coincidence, but a few months after those initial viral articles, the TSP board brought in outside consultants to review their I Fund index after 15 years of following the same geographically-limited MSCI EAFE. 
https://t.co/yblAkHTu7H

These articles were read by tens of thousands of federal/military investors and personnel, and since then I‚Äôve been a regular columnist on several federal news sites covering the TSP. It‚Äôs an area I have watched and written about weekly for years as a niche topic.

This article was the most-read commentary on the Federal News Network in 2016, presenting a bearish I Fund view (and I Fund did underperform over next 3yr): 
https://t.co/jxfqiUHObr

And this one went into more detail and suggested some EM exposure:  
https://t.co/ycEl7qvNKm

In late 2016, I released an infographic and set of articles that went rather viral across federal news sites about why the MSCI EAFE index was a lousy index for the only TSP international fund to follow, being so limited to slow-growth countries (Japan and Europe, mainly).

Although the overall TSP has over $500 billion in assets under management, the I Fund is one of the smaller funds with about $50 billion in assets. Investors get to choose which funds they invest in, and how much. They don't have to hold the I Fund if they don't want to.

The ‚ÄúI Fund‚Äù is the TSP‚Äôs only international stock fund, and since inception in 2001, it has followed the MSCI EAFE index, meaning it has only developed market exposure. No emerging markets, and no China except a tiny allocation to Hong Kong.

For context, the U.S. Thrift Savings Plan (TSP) for federal civilian and military personnel has five funds. The G Fund invests directly in treasuries. The other four funds invest in index funds (S&P 500, small caps, aggregate bonds, and international stocks.)

News source: 
https://t.co/Ngn3T6tJjk

This sort of thing has some bipartian support recently; it's not really a Republican or Democratic partisan issue. 

So, while it is political, it's not really partisan.

@JeffTay69071932 Marginal buyer sets the price, and most volume is on secondary market, although we did see big rate climb in September. Institutions are happy to buy bills/notes, but simply have finite space. If Fed didn't fix repo, space would hit hard limit and yields would rise.

@JeffTay69071932 Most gov debt is short-term bills/notes. Retail/funds hold a lot of the long-term bonds, which is a small percentage of total debt. The oversupply problem is likely happening at the institution level with sheer volume of short-term bills.

@uofkybear Nobody really has a problem with the price, just the volume. Like finishing a good piece of chocolate cake and then being given three more. They're good, and you could probably resell them, but your space is limited. If Fed didn't plug repo, rates would have to rise. Space issue.

@uofkybear That was all secondary market trading during that period. The only 10-year auction was 9/16. Auctions have been messy all year, with weak bid/cover ratios and long tails. Rates did go up substantially in September.
